'''Bahá'í studies''' refers to the scholarly study of the [[Bahá'í Faith]], its [[Bahá'í teachings|teachings]], [[History of the Bahá'í Faith|history]] and [[Bahá'í literature|literature]]. Bahá'í studies are currently conducted in a variety of venues, including institutes of the [[Bahá'í administration]] as well as non-affiliated universities. Some scholars study some aspect of the Bahá'í Faith as part of research on related matters while others engage in Bahá'í studies as a primary focus of their research. Scholars' comments on the religion and its predecessor [[Bábism]] date back to the at least 1845, the year after its founding. Initially they were often [[Orientalism|Orientalist]]s or [[Christian missionaries]] but through time both Bahá'ís and non-Bahá'í researchers have addressed the religion especially in tune with the [[Growth of religion#Bahá'í Faith|growth of the religion]], which has been called significant.
==Organizations==
* Association for Bahá’í Studies<ref>{{cite web |url= http://bahai-studies.ca/ |title= Association for Bahá’í Studies |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> - founded in 1975, the ABS operates under the supervision of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá’ís of Canada. * Bahá'í Library Online<ref name="Bahá'í Library Online">{{cite web |url= http://bahai-library.com/ |title= Bahá'í Library Online |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> − a private, independent, all-volunteer project created by Jonah Winters and a team of contributors. * Bahá'í Reference Library<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.bahai.org/library/ | title =Bahá’í Reference Library | date =2016 | website =Bahai.org | publisher =Bahá'í International Community | access-date =October 3, 2016 }}</ref> − an agency of the [[Bahá'í International Community]], hosts authorized writings of the religion.
* H-Bahai<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.h-net.org/~bahai/ |title= H-Bahai|date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= October 17, 2016}}</ref> - part of H-Net, an international interdisciplinary organization of scholars, H-Bahai is a website making available a wealth of difficult-to-obtain primary sources on the religion. * Irfan Colloquium<ref>[http://irfancolloquia.org/about/ Irfan Colloquium], About</ref> * [[Landegg International University]] - a now defunct university that operated from 1992 to 2003 under the aegis of the Bahá’í community of Switzerland * Unity Museum<ref>[http://unitymuseum.org/about/ The Unity Museum, A Bahá'í perspective on peace]</ref> is an award-winning boutique<ref>{{cite web | url =http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs138/1101372674346/archive/1123475627506.html | title =WA Baha'i History Museum ranked #2 best museum in Western Washinngton | date =February 2016 | website =The U District Partnership Newsletter | publisher = | access-date = October 3, 2016}}</ref> tax-exempt non-profit member of the [[Washington Museum Association]] and [[American Alliance of Museums]], separate from the formal organizational structure of the Bahá’í Faith, with its own board of directors, in Seattle, Washington, located near the [[University of Washington]].
* Wilmette Institute<ref>{{cite web |url= http://wilmetteinstitute.org/ |title= Wilmette Institute |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> - founded in 1995 as an educational endeavor of the National Spiritual Assembly of the United States, the Wilmette Institute provides on-line and on-site summer residential sessions. * Mediathèque {{not a typo|Baha'ie}} Francophone<ref>[http://www.bahai-biblio.org/ Mediatheque Baha'ie Francophone]</ref>
==Journals== {{see also|Bahá'í literature}}
* ''Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland'' or ''Bahá'í Journal UK'' some issues of which were digitized and is preserved online at [https://web.archive.org/web/20080209213354/http://www.bahaijournal.org.uk/archives.htm Archive.org] (2000–2004). See also [http://bahai-library.com/bahai_journal_united_kingdom at Bahai-Library.com] Then the periodical was redone and called the UK Baha'i Journal. * ''[[Bahá'í Studies Review]]'' * H-Bahai Digital Publications Series − published by H-Bahai, consisting of ''Occasional Papers in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies''; ''Research Notes in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies; Documents on the Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Movements''; and ''Translations of Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Primary Texts'' * Irfan Colloquia, consisting of ''Safini-yi 'Irfán'': Papers Presented at the `Irfán Colloquia (in Persian); ''Lights of `Irfán'': Papers Presented at the `Irfán Colloquia and Seminars (in English), and ''Beiträge des 'Irfán-Kolloquiums'': 'Irfán-Studien zum Bahá'í-Schrifttum (in German) * ''The Journal of Bahá’í Studies'' − published by the Association for Bahá’í Studies.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://bahai-studies.ca |title= Association for Bahá’í Studies |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> * ''UK Baha'i Review'', various issues of which were digitized and is preserved online at [https://web.archive.org/web/20100814192907/http://www.bahai.org.uk/uk_review/ Archive.org] (2001–2005) * ''World Order Magazine'' (published 1935–1949 and 1966–2002)<ref>[http://wilmetteinstitute.org/world-order-magazines-topical-index-now-available-on-the-wilmette-institute-website/ World Order Magazine's "Topical Index" Now Available on the Wilmette Institute Website], by Robert Stockman, Wilmetteinstitute.org, November 29, 2014</ref>
==Academic chairs==
* Baha'i Chair for Studies in Development<ref>{{cite web |url= http://bahaichairdavv.org/|title= Baha’I Chair for Studies in Development |date= |website= Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya |publisher= |access-date= September 28, 2016}}</ref> - at [[Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya]] in Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India. * Baha'i Chair for World Peace<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bahaipeacechair.umd.edu/ |title= Bahai Chair for World Peace |date= |website= University of Maryland |publisher= |access-date= September 28, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> - at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]] in College Park, Maryland, United States of America. * Chair in Bahá’í Studies<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hum.huji.ac.il/english/units.php?cat=3479&incat=0 |title= Moshe Sharon |author=<!-- Staff writer(s); no by-line. --> |date= |website= Hebrew University of Jerusalem, The Faculty of Humanities, Chair in Baha'i Studies |publisher= |access-date= September 28, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> - at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] in Jerusalem, Israel. * Lecture Series in Baha'i Studies, [[Meir & Miriam Ezri Center for Iran and Persian Gulf Studies]], [[University of Haifa]]<ref>[http://gulfc2.haifa.ac.il/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=8&id=61&Itemid=31 Lecture Series in Baha'i Studies], The Meir & Miriam Ezri Center for Iran and Persian Gulf Studies, University of Haifa, Mount Carmel, Haifa 31905, Israel, October 1, 2016</ref>
==Archives and collections==
===Bahá'í archives/collections===
A number of collections of Bahá'í related materials are preserved around the world. Some are maintained at universities; the [[Bahá'í World Centre buildings#The Arc buildings|Bahá'í World Center]], especially at the Centre for the Study of the Sacred Texts, the International Archives, and International Bahá'í Library, most National Bahá'í Assemblies and many local Bahá'í assemblies or institutions maintain their own archives.
====Academic====
* Ghassem Ghani<ref>[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/gani- Ghassem Ghani], Iranica Online, by Abbas Milani, Originally Published: December 15, 2000</ref> Collection, at Yale University,<ref>[http://drs.library.yale.edu/HLTransformer/HLTransServlet?stylename=yul.ead2002.xhtml.xsl&pid=mssa:ms.0235&clear-stylesheet-cache=yes Ghassem Ghani collection], Manuscripts and Archives, Sterling Memorial Library, 128 Wall Street, P.O. Box 208240, New Haven, CT 06520</ref> 1800–1900, 3.5 linear feet (1 box, 2 folios) in Persian. * Jamshed & Parvati Fozdar Collection at the [[National Library of Singapore]].<ref>[http://www.nlb.gov.sg/donors/jamshed-parvati-fozdar-collection/ Jamshed & Parvati Fozdar Collection], National Library of Singapore</ref> * Baron Victor Rosen's collection in the [[Archive of the Russian Academy of Sciences]], St. Petersburg branch.<ref>[http://www.orientalstudies.ru/eng/images/pdf/p_wmo_2_2015_08_ioannesyan.pdf The St. Petersburg 19th c. Collection of Materials on the Babi and Baha’i Faiths: Primary and other Sources], Youli Ioannesyan, Institute of Oriental manuscripts, Russian Academy of Sciences, July 10, 2015</ref><ref>[http://irfancolloquia.org/54/ioannesyan_petersburg The St. Petersburg 19th Century Orientalist Collection of Materials on the Babi and Baha'i Faiths: Primary and Other Sources], by Ioannesyan, Y., in ''Lights of Irfan'' 7: 75-100, 2006</ref> * Badi’u’lláh and Muhammad Ali Baha’i Papers, 1901–1944, Burke Library Archives, Columbia University Libraries, Union Theological Seminary, New York<ref>[http://library.columbia.edu/content/dam/libraryweb/locations/burke/fa/mrl/ldpd_4492535.pdf Badi’u’lláh and Muhammad Ali Baha’i Papers, 1901–1944], Burke Library Archives, Columbia University Libraries, Union Theological Seminary, New York</ref> * Hurqalya Publications: Center for Shaykhī and Bābī-Bahā’ī Studies by Stephen Lambden, University of California, Merced.<ref>[http://hurqalya.ucmerced.edu/ Hurqalya Publications: Center for Shaykhī and Bābī-Bahā’ī Studies] by Stephen Lambden, University of California, Merced</ref>
====Bahá'í sponsored====
* US National Bahai Archives, for [[Louhelen Bahá'í School]] Library, and the National Baha'i Library, US<ref>[https://bnl.follettdestiny.com/common/welcome.jsp?context=saas16_1208724 Welcome to National Bahai Archives, US]</ref><ref>[http://wilmetteinstitute.org/catalog-for-the-national-bahai-library-now-available/ Catalog for the U.S. National Bahá’í Library Now Available], by Robert Stockman, December 31, 2014</ref> * Eliot Baha'i Archives<ref>[http://eliotbahai.mainememory.net/page/2341/display.html Eliot Baha'i Archives]</ref> associated with [[Green Acre Bahá'í School]] * Los Angeles Baha'i Archives on Facebook,<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/Los-Angeles-Bahai-Archives-600786379946901/ Los Angeles Baha'i Archives] on Facebook</ref> and YouTube.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCq8f_v7hEL8usKhR43QwwfA Los Angeles Baha'i Center]</ref> * Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Washington, D.C. Archives<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/main/religion/bow.html Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Washington, D.C. Archives], Religion Collections in Libraries and Archives: A Guide to Resources in Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia, Humanities & Social Sciences division, Library of Congress</ref>
==Publishing==
A number of venues exist for publishing materials related to the Bahá'í Faith.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/rg/rg.publishers.html | title =Publishing Houses and Journals | date =2016 | website = Bahai-library.com | access-date =October 3, 2016}}</ref> Many national assemblies have their own publishing trust and there are a few publishing houses that run more or less independently. Among them are:
* BahaiBookStore.com<ref>[http://www.bahaibookstore.com/ BahaiBookStore.com]</ref> the Bahá'í Distribution Service acting as an agency of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States * BahaiBooksUK is the publishing trust of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.bahaibooks.org.uk/PBCPPlayer.asp?ID=1212825 About Us], BahaiBooks.org.uk</ref> * BahaiBooks is the publishing trust of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Australia, founded in 1976.<ref>[http://www.bahaibooks.com/aboutus About Us], Baha'i Publications Australia</ref> * The Baha'i Publishing Trust of India.<ref>[http://www.bahaipublishingtrust.in/ Baha'i Publishing Trust, New Delhi, India]</ref> * Oneworld Publications<ref>[https://oneworld-publications.com/ Oneworld Publications]</ref> founded in 1986 in the UK<ref>[https://oneworld-publications.com/about About Us]</ref> has published Baha'i books.<ref>[https://oneworld-publications.com/books/non-fiction/religion/baha-i.html Baha'i books] on Oneworld Publications</ref> * Kalimát Press<ref>[http://www.kalimat.com/ Kalimát Press]</ref> is a small, privately owned Baha'is publishing company. * ''Bahá’í Encyclopedia Project'' was also established by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States for invited scholars to contribute scholarly articles.<ref>[http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=58&Itemid=56 Bahá’í Encyclopedia Project], About</ref>
==Scholarship==
Starting with the antecedent [[Bábísm]] religion, as viewed by Bahá'ís,<ref>{{cite book | author=Christopher Buck | editor1=[[Moshe Sharon]] | editor2= W. J. Hanegraaff |editor3=P. Pratap Kumar | title =Studies in Modern Religions and Religious Movements and the Babi/Baha'i Faiths |chapter=The eschatology of globalization: the multiple-messiahship of Bahá'ulláh revisited | chapterurl=http://christopherbuck.com/pdf/Buck_2004_Globalization.pdf | publisher =Brill Academic Publishers | series =Mumen Book Series, Studies in the history of religions | volume =CIV | date =August 2004 | pages =143–173 | url =https://www.questia.com/library/117757165/studies-in-modern-religions-and-religious-movements | isbn = 9789004139046 }}</ref> scholarship on the religion began in its earliet days.<ref name="Momen1981">{{citation | last = Momen | year = 1981 | first = Moojan | title = The Babi and Baha'i Religions, 1844-1944: Some Contemporary Western Accounts | location = Oxford, England |publisher = George Ronald | isbn = 0-85398-102-7}}</ref>
While there were previous Iran or near-Iranian sources of scholarship of the religion in early periods, wide-ranging publications covering mostly western literature include Moojan Momens' 1981 '''The Babi and Baha'i Religions, 1844–1944: Some Contemporary Western Accounts''',<ref name="Momen1981" /> William Collins' 1992 '''Bibliography of English-language works on the Bábí and Bahá'í faiths, 1844–1985''',<ref name="Collins">{{cite book|author=William P. Collins|title=Bibliography of English-language works on the Bábí and Bahá'í faiths, 1844–1985|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ixMZAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=29 April 2013|year=1990|publisher=G. Ronald|isbn=978-0-85398-315-6}}</ref> and MacEoin's annotated bibliography borrowing heavily from Collins' work.<ref>{{cite web | last = MacEoin | first = Denis| title = The Babi and Baha'i Religions: An Annotated Bibliography | publisher = Greenwood Press's ongoing series of Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies | url =http://bahai-library.com/maceoin_annotated_bibliography| accessdate = October 3, 2016 }}</ref> There is also the '''Resource Guide for the Scholarly Study of the Bahá'í Faith''' by Robert Stockman and Jonah Winters published in 1997,<ref>[http://bahai-library.com/stockman_winters_resource_guide Resource Guide for the Scholarly Study of the Bahá'í Faith], by Robert Stockman and Jonah Winters, Wilmette, IL: Research Office of the Bahá'í National Center, 1997</ref> focusing more on later works. Mostly these works explicitly ignored newspaper accounts.
===19th century===
A wide variety of accounts, encounters and investigations began to circulate outside of Persia as events began to unfold from the Spring of 1844 with the [[Declaration of the Báb]]. Initially viewed as an Iranian development and often through Christian missionary perspectives, the [[growth of religion]]<ref>{{cite book| last =Johnson| first =Todd M. |author2=Brian J. Grim | title =The World's Religions in Figures: An Introduction to International Religious Demography |chapter =Global Religious Populations, 1910–2010 |chapterurl =https://dx.doi.org/10.1002/9781118555767.ch1|publisher =John Wiley & Sons| date =26 March 2013| pages =59–62| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=CkFVF8nFiqkC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA59#v=onepage&q&f=false|doi =10.1002/9781118555767.ch1| isbn = 9781118555767}}</ref> would soon far transcend that limited perspective.

GIlmore | title = Babism | encyclopedia =The New Schaff-Herzog Encyclopedia of Religious Knowledge | editor1= Samuel MacCauley Jackson|editor2=Charles Colebrook Sherman | editor3=George William Gilmore | volume =2 | pages = 935–939 | publisher =republished by Christian Classics Ethereal Library | origyear =1910–1911? | year = 1952 | url =http://www.ccel.org/download.html?url=/ccel/schaff/encyc01.pdf | accessdate = October 16, 2013 }}</ref> The second, "Behaism", was by Margaret Bloodgood Peeke, "Inspectress-General of the Martinist Order of America" with nothing newer than 1906 in the bibliography.<ref>(warning, slow download) {{cite encyclopedia | author=Margaret Bloodgood Peeke | title = Behaism | encyclopedia =The New Schaff-Herzog Encyclopedia of Religious Knowledge | editor1= Samuel MacCauley Jackson|editor2=Charles Colebrook Sherman | editor3=George WIlliam Gilmore | volume =2 | pages = 104–105 | publisher =republished by Christian Classics Ethereal Library | origyear =1910–1911? | year = 1952 | url = http://www.ccel.org/download.html?url=/ccel/schaff/encyc02.pdf | accessdate = October 17, 2016 }}</ref> Peeke had gone on to visit `Abdu'l-Bahá as a non-Bahá'í in 1899 and judged it to be "living the life" of the teachings of Jesus Christ.<ref>[http://bahai-library.com/margaretpeeke_1899_abbaseffendi_visit My Visit to Abbas-Effendi in 1899], by Margaret B. Peeke, page 10 and 16.</ref> * In early 1911 unitarian minister [[Celia Parker Woolley]] advertised a meeting discussing the religion in the African newspaper [[The Chicago Defender]].<ref>"Frederick Douglass Center, 2032 Wabash Ave", ''The Chicago Defender'', [Chicago, Ill] 29 April 1911: p. 1.</ref> In late 1911 [[E. S. Drower|Ethel Stefana Stevens]] published two articles in widely circulated magazines - ''Forthnightly Review'',<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=4nzPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1067#v=onepage&q&f=false Abbas Effendi: His personality, work, and followers], by E. S. Stevens, The Forthnightly Review, New series vol 95, no 534 June 1, 1911, pp. 1067–1084</ref> and ''Everybody's Magazine''.<ref>[http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015012320191;view=1up;seq=803 The light in the lantern], by Ethel Stefana Stevens, Everybody's Magazine, vol 24, no 6, December 1911, pp. 755–786</ref> a variety of 1911 mentions occur in newspapers - Ghodsea Ashrof emigratig,<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1083336/bahai_ghodsea_ashrof_talks_at_meeting/ Ghodsea Ashrof speaks at Bahaists meeting], ''The Washington Times'' (Washington, District of Columbia) 19 June 1911 • First Edition, p. 4</ref> conditions in Iran,<ref>[http://fultonhistory.com/Process%20Small/Newspapers/Utica%20NY%20Saturday%20Globe/Utica%20NY%20Saturday%20Globe%201909-1911%20pdf/Utica%20NY%20Saturday%20Globe%201909-1911%20-%201105.pdf Growing Persian sect], Utica Saturday Globe, July 8, 1911, p. 10, 2nd col mid</ref> and specifically women's rights,<ref>[http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201911%20a%20%20Grayscale/New%20York%20NY%20Sun%201911%20a%20%20Grayscale%20-%203630.pdf Women's rights in orient], ''The NY Sun'', October 1, 1911, p. 8, 7th col, down from top</ref><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24991/babibahai_history/ "Women's Rights in Orient"], ''The Hutchinson News'', Hutchinson, Kansas, October 5, 1911, p. 12, 5th column, from middle</ref> Behaists/"TruthKnowers",<ref>[http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2021/Whitesville%20NY%20News/Whitesville%20NY%20News%201911-1913/Whitesville%20NY%20News%201911-1913%20-%200075.pdf How Christmas grew to be what it is toeay - waiting for the Messiah and a New Christmas], by Henry Tyrrell, ''The Whitesville News'', December 21, 1911, p. 3, see 3rd col near middle</ref> a large article about the coming of `Abdul'-Bahá to the West of his presence in Europe.<ref>[http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald/New%20York%20NY%20Herald%201911/New%20York%20NY%20Herald%201911%20-%205951.pdf The Coming of Abbas Effendi, Messiah of 6,000,000 Souls], ''New York Herald'', December 31, 1911, p. 4, top</ref><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24994/babibahai_history/ "The Coming of the Abbas Effendi, Messia go 6,000,000 Souls"], ''The Washington Post'', December 31, 1911, p. 1, upper half.</ref> Rev. Peter Z. Easton, a Presbyterian in the [[Synod of the Northeast]] in New York who was stationed in [[Tabriz]], Iran from 1873 to 1880, didn't have an appointment to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá in Bristol, UK.<ref>{{cite web | title = Minutes of the ... annual session of the Synod of New York | work = | publisher =Presbyterian in the Synod of the Northeast | date = March 29, 1914 | url = https://archive.org/stream/minutesofannuals1914pres/minutesofannuals1914pres_djvu.txt | accessdate = 2010-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | editor-last = Rev. Simpson | editor-first = Albert B | editor2-last = Rev. Smith | editor2-first = Eugene R. | title = Persia Mission of the Presbytrian Church, Independent Mission Work In Persia and the Caucasus | journal = The Gospel in All Lands | volume = 04 | issue = 4 | pages = 175–177 | publisher = Bible House | location = New York | date = October 1881 | url =http://www.cmalliance.org/resources/archives/downloads/gospel-in-all-lands/gospel-in-all-lands-1881-10.pdf | accessdate = 2010-03-14 | ref = harv }}</ref> Easton attempted to meet and challenge `Abdu'l-Bahá and in his actions made those around him uncomfortable; `Abdu'l-Bahá withdrew him to a private conversation and then he left. Later he printed a polemic attack on the religion, ''Bahaism — A Warning'', in the ''Evangelical Christendom'' newspaper of London.<ref>{{cite book |author=Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl Gulpáygání | origyear = 1912 |year=1998 |title=The Brilliant Proof |location=Los Angeles | publisher=Kalimát Press |url= http://bahai-library.com/books/brilliant.proof/appendix.html#Heading11 | page = APPENDIX Bahaism — A Warning, by Peter Z. Easton }}</ref> and echoed.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1054970/rev_eastons_challenge_to_abdulbaha/ Warns Americans against Baha], The Hawaiian Star(Honolulu, Hawaii)11 May 1912 • First Edition</ref> The polemic was later responded to by [[Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl]] in his book ''The Brilliant Proof'' written in December 1911.<ref>''Burhan-i-Lami`'' (The Brilliant Proof): Published, along with an English translation, in Chicago in 1912, the paper responds to a Christian clergyman's questions. Republished as {{cite book |author=Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl Gulpáygání | origyear = 1912 |year=1998 |title=The Brilliant Proof |location=Los Angeles | publisher=Kalimát Press |url=http://bahai-library.com/gulpaygani_brilliant_proof}}</ref> * 1912 - A significant number of articles reviewed or mention [[`Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys to the West]]; see that article for significant mentions and reviews. However, separately, some mention the Faith of Abdu'l-Bahá before he came to the US such as by [[Gertrude Atherton]]<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2655500/mention_of_bahai_faith_in_fiction/ Love and Fire], Pittsburgh Daily Post (Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania)20 April 1912, Sat • Page 13 * {{cite book|author=Gertrude Franklin Horn Atherton|title=Julia France and Her Times: A Novel|url=https://archive.org/stream/juliafranceherti00athe#page/276/mode/2up |year=1912|publisher=John Murray}}</ref> or a few mentions were made aside from coverage about `Abdu'l-Bahá. [[Lua Getsinger]] gave a talk on the religion that was noted in ''The Pacific Unitarian''.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/pacificunitarian2019111912wilb#page/153/mode/1up "The February meetings…"], ''The Pacific Unitarian - Devoted to Religious Truth and Higher Life'', March 1912, page 153, middle left column. Also refers to another publication mention it. - the ''Christian Register'' of Feb 18.</ref> [[Tahirih]] was noted more than once.<ref>* [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/204325/history_of_tahirih_quotes_browne_1912/ "Persian was first"], ''The Eufaula Republican'', (Eufaula, Oklahoma), 20 September 1912 • Page 4 * [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/204341/echo_of_report_on_tahirih/ "Persian was first"], ''The Huntington Press'', 10 September 1912 • Page 6</ref> The "Clio Information Club" hosted a talk by [[Howard MacNutt]] gave a talk in October as noted in the African American ''[[New York Age]]''.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/286449/the_new_york_age/ The members and a few friends of the Clio Information Club] ''The New York Age'', 10 October 1912 • Page 8</ref> The first mention of the religion so far found in the ''[[Pittsburgh Courier]]'' occur when a "Mrs. Davis" held a meeting at her home for a club and the topic was the religion.<ref>{{cite news | title =The Aurora Reading club… | newspaper =The Pittsburgh Courier | location =Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | page =5 | date =4 October 1912 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/406704/aurora_reading_club_hears_lecture_on/ | access-date =October 17, 2016 }}</ref> And there was mention in Australia.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article23872168 "Bahaism"], ''The West Australian'', Perth, West Australia, May 11, 1912, p. 7, 3rd and 4th columns, or as highlighted</ref> * In 1913 '''Persia, the Land of the Magi…''' was published by Samuel Kasha Nweeya.<ref>[http://www.general-books.net/book.cfm?id=1758709 '''Persia, the Land of the Magi…'''] by Nweeya, Samuel K. (Samuel Kasha), about 1913</ref> Also in 1913 the article "Key to the Heaven of the Beyan or a Third Call of Attention to the Behaists or Babists of America" was published by August J. Stenstrand for the Illinois State Historical Society.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/40193933 Editorial Notes] by Jessie Palmer Weber, Edward F. Dunne and Harry Woods, Journal of the Illinois State Historical Society (1908–1984), Vol. 6, No. 3 (October 1913), pp. 455-468 (p. 467)</ref> * In the July 1914 edition of ''The Harvard Theological Review'' then Reverend Albert R. Vail published an article surveying the religion.<ref>[http://bahai-library.com/vail_bahaism_contemporary_movement Bahaism: A Study of a Contemporary Movement], by Albert R. Vail, ''The Harvard Theological Review'', July 1914, pages 339-357</ref> Part 1 of "Bahaism and the Woman Question", by Rev. Samuel G. Wilson, in October ''Missionary Review of the World''.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=v2QwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA739#v=onepage&q&f=false "Bahaism and the Woman Question"], by Rev. Samuel G. Wilson, ''Missionary Review of the World'', Vol 37, published by Funk & Wagnalls, October 1914, pp. 739–745</ref> and was followed by part 2 in December.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=v2QwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA915#v=onepage&q&f=false "Bahaism and the Woman Question - II"], by Rev Samuel G Wilson, ''Missionary Review of the World'', Vol 37, published by Funk & Wagnalls, December 1914 pp. 915–919</ref> See [[Bahá'í Faith and gender equality]]. * In 1915 Robert P. Richardson published his first article in the ''Open Court''.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Richardson | first =Robert P. | title =The Persian Revival to Jesus, and his American Disciples | journal = The Open Court | volume =29 | issue =8 | pages =460–483 | date=August 1915 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=_uoXAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA460#v=onepage&q&f=false | accessdate = October 17, 2016}}</ref> In 1916 [[Mary Bird (medical missionary)|Mary Bird]] mentioned the religion in a missionary light.<ref>[http://anglicanhistory.org/me/ir/bird1916/03.html Mary Bird in Persia], By Clara C. Rice, London: Church Missionary Society, 1916.</ref> In 1917 Albert Vail, along with his wife Emily McClellan Vail, published a two volume set of books each with a chapter about the religion: "Heroic lives" for sixth grade curriculums with student and teacher notebooks.<ref>* [https://archive.org/stream/heroiclives00vailgoog#page/n248/mode/2up Heroic lives], (Student notebook) by Albert R. Vail and Emily McClellan Vail, Pub - Boston, Beacon Press, 1917 * [https://archive.org/stream/heroiclivesinun00vailgoog#page/n316/mode/2up/ Heroic lives], (Teacher notebook) by Albert R. Vail and Emily McClellan Vail, Pub - Boston, Beacon Press, 1917</ref> * [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] died in 1921 and was a major event in the region with thousands attending the procession of the casket, and prominent local representatives of Muslim, Christian, and Jewish communities speaking on the occasion.<ref>{{cite book|title=Religious Bodies, 1936|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AEroFULgjXUC&pg=PA80|year=1941|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|page=80}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Shoghi Effendi|title=The Passing of ʻAbduʼl-Bahá: A Compilation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TeFVPBHvGh4C|year=1991|publisher=Kalimat Press|isbn=978-0-933770-82-9}}</ref> Obituaries appeared in the New York,<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/444488/obit_of_abdulbaha_from_london_times/ Abdul Baha, religious leader, dies in Persia], ''New York Tribune'' (New York, New York) 1 December 1921, Thu • Page 1</ref> Los Angeles<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6313804/obit_and_picture_of_abdulbaha/ Bahai movement leader is dead], ''The Los Angeles Times'' (Los Angeles, California) 1 December 1921, Thu • Page 1</ref> and elsewhere, based out of reports announced in London news. * In 1924, American Ambassador to the Qajar dynasty of Persia, Robert Imbrie was [[Attacks on U.S. diplomatic facilities|killed]] on suspicion of being a Bahá'í.<ref>{{cite journal | title =Blood, Power, and Hypocrisy: The Murder of Robert Imbrie and American Relations with Pahlavi Iran, 1924 | url = http://scholarworks.boisestate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=history_facpubs | accessdate =April 21, 2014 | journal= [[International Journal of Middle East Studies]] | publisher=Cambridge University Press | last=Zirinsky | first=Michael | volume=18 | issue=3 | date=August 1986 | pages=275–292 | doi=10.1017/S0020743800030488}}</ref> * [[Juan Cole]] — historian, Richard P. Mitchell Collegiate Professor of History at the [[University of Michigan]]. * [[Denis MacEoin]] — historian, Senior Fellow at the [[Gatestone Institute]] and a Fellow at the [[Middle East Forum]]. * [[William McElwee Miller]] — missionary, Christian minister, and translator. * [[Suheil Bushrui]] <ref name=Canada>[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/type,QUERYRESPONSE,,LBN,41501c2b1c,0.html Lebanon: Situation of Baha'is], [[Government of Canada]], 2004-04-16</ref> was a professor, author, poet, critic, translator, and peace maker as a prominent scholar in regard to the life and works of [[Kahlil Gibran]], published more than one volume about him,<ref name="Bushrui 55">{{cite book|title=Kahlil Gibran, Man and Poet: a New Biography|year=1998|publisher=Oneworld Publications|author=Bushrui, Suheil B.|author2=Jenkins, Joe|page=55|isbn=978-1851682676| url=http://bahai-library.com/bushrui_gibran_man_poet}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Gibran |first=Khalil |year= 1983 |title=Blue Flame: The Love Letters of Khalil Gibran to May Ziadah |others=edited and translated by [[Suheil Bushrui]] and Salma Kuzbari |location=Harlow, England |publisher=Longman|isbn=0-582-78078-0}}</ref> and served as the Kahlil Gibran Chair for Values and Peace at the [[University of Maryland]]<ref name=BBC12May12>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17997163 Kahlil Gibran's The Prophet: Why is it so loved?], BBC News, May 12, 2012, Retrieved May 12, 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.umd.edu/chrsweb/Gibran/Gibran_Chair_Report.htm |title=The Kahlil Gibran Chair for Values and Peace at the Center for Heritage Resource Studies The University of Maryland |publisher=Heritage.umd.edu |accessdate=December 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730115042/http://www.heritage.umd.edu/CHRSWeb/Gibran/Gibran_Chair_Report.htm |archivedate=July 30, 2012 }}</ref> and winner of the Juliet Hollister Awards from the [[Temple of Understanding]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steinergraphics.com/bahaichair/news001.html |title=Professor Suheil Bushrui Receives Juliet Hollister Award |publisher=Steinergraphics.com |date=August 20, 2003 |accessdate=December 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304130019/http://www.steinergraphics.com/bahaichair/news001.html |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref>
===21st century=== * [[Margit Warburg]] published a book on the history of the Bahá'ís focusing on the Danish Bahá'í community in 2006.<ref>{{cite book|author=Margit Warburg|author-link=Margit Warburg|title=Citizens of the World: A History and Sociology of the Bahaʹis from a Globalisation Perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tAvXAAAAMAAJ|year=2006|publisher=Brill|isbn=978-90-04-14373-9}}</ref> * Leigh Eric Schmidt devoted a chapter of his '''Restless Souls: The Making of American Spirituality''' published by the University of California Press on the history and impact of [[Green Acre Bahá'í School]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Leigh Eric Schmidt|title=Restless Souls: The Making of American Spirituality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wbk80IOIgzEC|date=6 August 2012|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-95411-3}}</ref> * The peer-reviewed [[Journal of Religious History]] issued a special edition devoted to the Bahá'í Faith in December 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jorh.2012.36.issue-4/issuetoc | title =''Journal of Religious History'', Special Issue: Baha'i History | volume =36 | issue =4 |editor=Todd Lawson | date =December 2012 | website =Wiley Online Library |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9809.2012 | publisher =Religious History Association | access-date =December 26, 2016 }}</ref> * [[Abbas Amanat]] — historian, Professor of History & International Studies at [[Yale University]]. * [http://toddlawson.ca/ Todd Lawson] — Associate Professor Emeritus of Islamic Thought at the [https://www.utoronto.ca/ University of Toronto]. * [[M. Şükrü Hanioğlu]] — historian, professor of late Ottoman history in the Department of Near Eastern Studies at [[Princeton University]]. * [[Moojan Momen]] — historian, author of numerous books and articles about the Baha’i Faith. * [https://www.binghamton.edu/cnes/people/faculty/omid_ghaemmaghami.html Omid Ghaemmaghami] — Professor of Arabic at SUNY, Binghamton, * [[Peter Smith (historian)|Peter Smith]] — historian, currently on faculty at [[Mahidol University International College]] in Thailand. * [[Moshe Sharon]] — historian, Professor Emeritus of Islamic and Middle Eastern Studies at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] where he serves as Chair in Bahá'í Studies. * [[Ehsan Yarshater]] — Persianist, Hagop Kevorkian Professor Emeritus of Iranian Studies at [[Columbia University]].
==Bahá'í review== {{main|Bahá'í review}} Bahá'í scholars who are also members of the faith must submit their work for [[Bahá'í review|review]] by the [[Bahá'í administration]] and obtain prior approval. According to the administration of the religion, the purpose of the review is threefold:<ref>{{cite book|title=Lights of Guidance|page=101|url=http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance.html&chapter=2|editor=Helen Hornby}}</ref>
* To ensure the accuracy of the presentation of the teachings of the religion * To protect the religion from misrepresentation by its own followers * To ensure dignity of the form
[[Juan Cole]], a former Bahá'í who had disagreements with the Bahá'í administration on account of the [[Bahá'í review|review]] describes it as "a system of in-house censorship" which "has provoked many conflicts between Bahá'í officials and writers over the years."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cole |first= Juan R.I. | authorlink = Juan Cole | last2= |first2= |date= June 1998 |title= The Baha’i Faith in America as Panopticon, 1963-1997 | url= http://www-personal.umich.edu/~jrcole/bahai/1999/jssr/bhjssr.htm |journal= The Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion |publisher= |volume= 37 |issue= 2 |pages= |doi= |access-date= September 30, 2016 }}</ref> There have been several conflicts originating from the practice of review, and a number of prominent academics, including [[Juan Cole]], [[Denis MacEoin]] and [[Abbas Amanat]], have either been excommunicated or forced to resign due to academic disagreements with the religious hierarchy. Denis MacEoin has said that the review has stifled research in Bahá'í studies.<ref>{{cite journal |last= MacEoin |first= Denis| authorlink = Denis MacEoin| last2= |first2= |date= 1990 |title= The crisis in Babi and Baha'i studies: part of a wider crisis in academic freedom? |url= http://fglaysher.com/bahaicensorship/archives/Denis%20MacEoin,%20Crisis%20in%20Babi%20and%20Baha'i%20Studies.pdf |journal= British Journal of Middle Eastern Studies |publisher= |volume= 17 |issue= 1 |pages= 55–61|doi=10.1080/13530199008705506 |access-date= September 30, 2016}}</ref> Moojan Momen, another academic in the field of Bahá'í Studies who has labeled Juan Cole and Denis MacEoin "apostates," disagrees and states that "there is no more 'censorship' involved in this process than with any other academic journal."<ref>{{cite journal | title= Marginality and Apostasy in the Bahá'í Community | url= http://bahai-library.com/momen_marginality_apostasy| first = Moojan | last= Momen | journal="Religion" | pages = 187–209 | year = 2007 | number = 37:3 }}</ref>

'''Beta dispersion''' is the phenomenon associated with the ability of a biological cell membrane to filter out low frequency [[Electric current|currents]] and allow high frequency currents to pass through. It was originally hypothesized by [[Rudolf Höber]] in 1910.<ref>Polk C., Postow E. Handbook of biological effects of electromagnetic fields. CRC Press, 1996.</ref>
==See also== * [[alpha dispersion]]

In video technology, '''blanking level''' is the level of the [[composite video signal]] during the front and back porches of the video signal.
The composite video signal is actually the video information superimposed on blanking. The total level of the composite video signal (blanking + video) is 1000 mV. This level can also be given in [[IRE (unit)|IRE]] units such that the level difference reserved for video information is 100 IRE units. So white corresponds to 100 IRE units and blanking level corresponds to 0 IRE units. The level of black is 0 IRE units in the case of [[CCIR System B]] and [[CCIR System G]] (European systems) and 7.5 IRE units in the case of [[CCIR System M]] (American system).<ref>[http://www.kolumbus.fi/pami1/video/pal_ntsc.html Kolumbus page]</ref> So, while there is no difference between the black and the blanking levels in most systems they differ by 50 mV. in system M. (When defined in terms of voltage difference, 7.5 IRE units is almost equal to 50 mV.) == References == <references/> {{Analogue TV transmitter topics}} [[Category:Television technology]] [[Category:Broadcast engineering]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = Chinese Arctic and Antarctic Administration
国家海洋局极地考察办公室
Guójiā hǎiyáng jú jídì kǎochá bàngōngshì |image = Chinese Arctic and Antarctic Administration.jpg |image_border = |size = 350px |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = CAA |motto = |formation = 1981 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = Organizes, coordinates and supervises China's polar program |headquarters = No.1 Fuxingmenwai Ave. 10086, Beijing, China |location = |coords = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = Director |leader_name = [[Qu Tanzhou]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[State Oceanic Administration]] |affiliations = [[International Arctic Research Center]];
[[International Arctic Science Committee]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.chinare.gov.cn/en/ www.chinare.gov.cn/en] |remarks = }} The '''Chinese Arctic and Antarctic Administration''' (CAA) (previously the '''Chinese Antarctic Administration of the State Antarctic Research Committee'''){{cite web|url=http://nsidc.org/pubs/notes/33/|title=NSIDC Notes, Issue 33|date=September 2000|work=National Snow and Ice Data Center|publisher=University of Colorado at Boulder|accessdate=27 July 2010}} is a [[Beijing]]-based agency of the [[People's Republic of China]]'s [[State Oceanic Administration]] (SOA). Established in 1981, it organizes China's scientific program for both the [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]], and it provides logistic support to Antarctic expeditions. There are several; divisions, including General Affairs, Operation & Logistics, Science Programs, International Cooperation, representation in the Chinese Embassy in [[Chile]], and a Winter Training Base.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinare.gov.cn/en/index.html?pid=about|title=A Brief Introduction to CAA|work=chinare.gov.cn|accessdate=27 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307224446/http://www.chinare.gov.cn/en/index.html?pid=about|archivedate=7 March 2010|df=}} The director is [[Qu Tanzhou]].{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2010-05/06/content_9814100.htm|title=Arctic research set to be beefed up|last=Qian|first=Wang|date=2010-05-06|work=[[China Daily]]|accessdate=27 July 2010}} The CAA organizes, coordinates and supervises China's polar program. As such, its responsibilities include: developing an integrated national polar research strategy, developing policy to guide national polar research activities, developing a five-year plan which coordinates the national policy, updating the national polar plan on an annual basis, coordinating the annual national polar research expedition, promoting coordination of polar research programs with other agencies, and supporting polar research cooperation with other nations and international organizations.{{cite book|last=Riffenburgh|first=Beau |title=Encyclopedia of the Antarctic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fRJtB2MNdJMC&pg=PA226&dq=Chinese+Arctic+and+Antarctic+Administration&hl=en&ei=ZTtOTMalFI_CsAOb39EL&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Chinese%20Arctic%20and%20Antarctic%20Administration&f=false|volume=1|year=2007 |publisher=CRC Press|isbn=0-415-97024-5|page=226}} The CAA is affiliated with the [[International Arctic Research Center]],{{cite web|url=http://www.iarc.uaf.edu/gmap/|title=IARC International Collaborations, Partners, and Related Organizations|date=2009-02-13|work=iarc.uaf.edu|publisher=IARC, University of Alaska, Fairbanks|accessdate=27 July 2010|location=Fairbanks|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515143417/http://www.iarc.uaf.edu/gmap/|archivedate=15 May 2008|df=}} and the [[International Arctic Science Committee]]. ==Projects== A 2006 ''[[Shanghai Daily]]'' news report stated that Chinese scientists would begin naming 46 newly surveyed, anonymous Antarctic islands and that the CAA, with its teammate [[Sina.com]], would collect candidate names.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/blogs/eyeonasia/archives/2006/04/china_enters_the_ice_age.html|title=China enters the Ice Age|last=Einhorn|first=Bruce|date=2006-04-03|work=[[Business Week]]|accessdate=27 July 2010}} From 2007 through 2009, the CAA organized a government sponsored research project to enhance its understanding of the legal, military and political issues associated with the Arctic. The agency also operates a winter training base at [[Yabuli Ski Resort]] in the northern province of [[Heilongjiang]]. The [[International Polar Year]] 2007-2008 China Programme included a partnership between the [[International Polar Foundation]], the CCA, and the [[Polar Research Institute of China]]. This included the participation of Jean de Pomereu, reporter and photographer, in the 25th CHINARE Expedition late in the year in 2008. He traveled aboard the Chinese [[icebreaker]], [[MV Xue Long|Xuelong]] ("Snow Dragon"), then reported from China's east Antarctic research station, [[Antarctic Zhongshan Station]].{{cite web|url=http://www.polarfoundation.org/projects/project_detail/panda_dome_a_station_25th_chinese_antarctic_expedition/|title=PANDA & Dome A station: 25th Chinese Antarctic Expedition|work=polarfoundation.org|accessdate=28 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222001358/http://www.polarfoundation.org/projects/project_detail/panda_dome_a_station_25th_chinese_antarctic_expedition/|archivedate=22 December 2010|df=}} The expedition team sent by the CAA was also entrusted with starting construction of the [[Antarctic Kunlun Station]], China's third Antarctic station.{{cite news|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090106/full/457134a.html|title=China builds inland Antarctic base|last=Qiu|first=Jane|date=2009-01-06|work=[[Nature News]]|accessdate=28 July 2010}} ''Xuelong'', China's only polar research icebreaker was purchased in 1993 from [[Ukraine]], and has made 24 research expeditions to the Antarctic and three to the Arctic. In 2009, the CAA began planning for a Chinese-built icebreaker due to China's expanding polar exploration activities.{{cite news|url=http://www.barentsobserver.com/china-to-boost-arctic-research.4781463.html|title=China to boost Arctic research|date=2010-05-06|work=barentsobserver.com|accessdate=27 July 2010}} The ship, named {{MV|Xue Long 2}}, was laid down in 2016 and is expected to enter service in 2019.{{cite web | url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/10/c_136669892.htm | title=First Chinese-built polar icebreaker gets name | publisher=Xinhua | date=10 October 2017 | accessdate=19 April 2018}} ==See also== {{Div col}} *[[Arctic policy of China]] *[[Arctic Yellow River Station]] {{div col end}} {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinare.gov.cn/caa/|title=CAAA Official Website|language=Chinese|accessdate=July 27, 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chinese Arctic and Antarctic Administration}} [[Category:Organizations established in 1981]] [[Category:Research institutes in China]] [[Category:Environmental research institutes]] [[Category:Arctic research]] [[Category:Exploration of Antarctica]] [[Category:China and the Antarctic]]

{{Infobox ancient site |name = Cladh Hallan |native_name = |alternate_name = |image = Bronze Age Settlement - geograph.org.uk - 1340839.jpg |alt = Photo of the site |caption = Remains of roundhouses at Cladh Hallan |map_type = Scotland Outer Hebrides |map_alt = |map_size = |location = [[South Uist]] |region = |coordinates = {{coord|57.17116|-7.40759|display=inline}} |type = |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = [[Bronze Age Britain|Bronze Age]] |cultures = |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = |archaeologists = |condition = |ownership = |public_access = Yes |website = |notes = }} '''Cladh Hallan''' ({{lang-gd|Cladh Hàlainn}}, {{IPA-gd|kʰl̪ˠɤɣ ˈhaːl̪ˠɪɲ}}) is an [[archaeology|archaeological]] site on the island of [[South Uist]] in the [[Outer Hebrides]] in [[Scotland]]. It is significant as the only place in [[Great Britain]] where [[prehistoric]] [[mummy|mummies]] have been found.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/archaeology/excavations_techniques/mummies_cladhhallan_01.shtml "Mummification in Bronze Age Britain"] [[BBC History]]. Retrieved 11 February 2008. Excavations were carried out there between 1988 and 2002, indicating the site was occupied from 2000 BC.[http://www.shef.ac.uk/archaeology/research/cladh-hallan "The Prehistoric Village at Cladh Hallan"]. [[University of Sheffield]]. Retrieved 21 Feb 2008. [[File:Cladh-Hallan Man.svg|thumb|upright|left|Composition of the male mummy:
blue: male c. 1600 BC
yellow: male c. 1500-1400 BC
red: male c. 1440-1360 BC]] In 2001, a team of [[archaeologist]]s found four [[skeleton]]s at the site, one of them a male who had died c. 1600 BC, and another a female who had died c. 1300 BC. (about the same time as King [[Tutankhamun]] of [[Egypt]]). At first the researchers did not realise they were dealing with mummies, since the [[soft tissue]] had decomposed and the skeletons had been [[burial|buried]]. But tests revealed that both bodies had not been buried until about 1120 BC, and that the bodies had been preserved shortly after death in a peat [[bog]] for 6 to 18 months. The preserved bodies were then apparently retrieved from the bog and set up inside a dwelling, presumably having religious significance. Archaeologists do not know why the bodies were buried centuries later. The Cladh Hallan skeletons differ from most [[bog body|bog bodies]] in two respects: unlike most bog bodies, they appear to have been put in the bog for the express purpose of preservation (whereas most bog bodies were simply interred in the bog), and unlike most bog bodies, their soft tissue was no longer preserved at the time of discovery. == Analysis == {{update section|date=January 2017}} The skeletons and other finds are being analysed in laboratories in Scotland, [[England]] and [[Wales]]. Following the provisions of the Treasure Trove Act, all the finds from Cladh Hallan, including the skeletons, will be allocated to a [[Scottish museum]] after the lengthy process of analysis and reporting is completed. According to recent anthropological and [[DNA]]-analysis the skeletons of a female and a male were compiled from body parts of at least 6 different human individuals.{{cite web | last = Kaufman | first = Rachel | authorlink = | title = "Frankenstein" Bog Mummies Discovered in Scotland; Two ancient bodies made from six people, new study reveals | work = National Geographic | publisher = | date = 2012-07-06 | url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/07/120706-bog-mummies-body-parts-frankenstein-ancient-science/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2012-07-09 }} == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == * {{Cite book | last =Parker Pearson | first =Michael | authorlink =Michael Parker Pearson | title =South Uist: Archaeology and History of a Hebridean Island | publisher =Tempus | year =2004 | location =Stroud | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =0-7524-2905-1 |display-authors=etal}} == External links == *{{gbmapping|NF7308121962}} * [http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/108429/details/south+uist+cladh+hallan South Uist, Cladh Hallan Roundhouses] Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland {{Bog body}} {{Prehistoric Western Isles}} {{coord|57.17116|N|7.40759|W|region:GB_source:enwiki-osgb36(NF733219)|display=title}} [[Category:2nd-millennium BC architecture in Scotland]] [[Category:Archaeology of death]] [[Category:Human remains (archaeological)]] [[Category:2001 in science]] [[Category:2001 in Scotland]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in the Outer Hebrides]] [[Category:Bronze Age Scotland]] [[Category:Bog bodies]] [[Category:South Uist]] [[Category:2001 archaeological discoveries]]

{{Underlinked|date=May 2015}} {{main article|Conservation-restoration of cultural heritage}} [[File:Antiques restoration.jpg|thumb|Antiques restoration]] A '''conservator-restorer''' is a professional responsible for the [[Conservation-restoration of cultural heritage|preservation of artistic and cultural artifacts]], also known as [[cultural heritage]].<ref>"[http://www.conservation-us.org/about-conservation#.WSymX8m1tPs About Conservation: What is conservation? What is a conservator?]". American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC). www.conservation-us.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> Conservators possess the expertise to preserve cultural heritage in a way that retains the integrity of the object, building or site, including its historical significance, context and aesthetic or visual aspects.<ref name="Defining2003">Defining the Conservator: Essential Competencies. (2003). Retrieved from http://www.conservation-us.org/docs/default-source/governance/defining-the-conservator-essential-competencies.pdf?sfvrsn=1.</ref> This kind of preservation is done by analyzing and assessing the condition of cultural property, understanding processes and evidence of deterioration, planning [[collections care]] or site management strategies that prevent damage, carrying out conservation treatments, and conducting research.<ref name="Careers2014">Careers in Conservation. (2014). Retrieved from http://www.conservation-us.org/publications-resources/careers-in-conservation/become-a-conservator#.VPPIxMaLTwN.</ref> A conservator's job is to ensure that the objects in a museum's collection are kept in the best possible condition, as well as to serve the museum's mission to bring art before the [[public]].<ref name="Neuman2011">Neuman, R. (2011). MFA Highlights: Conservation and Care of Museum Collections. Boston, MA: Museum of Fine Arts.</ref>
== Conservation and restoration == Essentially, the term "conservation" refers to a manner of care or treatment that repairs damage and also takes action to prevent or slow down further deterioration of an object.<ref name="Landry2000">Landry, G. (2000). The Wintertbur Guide to Caring for Your Collection. Winterthur, Delaware, DE: Winterthur Museum.</ref> The term "restoration" refers to a manner of care or treatment in which the goal is to bring an object back to its original appearance or function.<ref name="Landry2000" /> "Restoration" can be part of the care and treatment of an object and is a subset of the umbrella term "conservation".<ref name="Landry2000" /> Both terms come into play when it comes to the treatment and care of all cultural heritage.
== Responsibilities and duties == Conservators and restorers care for, manage, treat, preserve, and document many different historical items including [[Cultural artifact|artifacts]], [[art]], and specimens.<ref name="Baker2015">Baker, G. D. (2015). How to Become a Museum Conservator. Retrieved from http://collegemouse.com/jobs/how-to-become-a-museum-conservator.html.</ref>
* Examining artifacts, both visually and using scientific tools such as x-rays, infrared photography and microscopic analysis to determine the extent and causes of deterioration.<ref name="Johnston2013">Johnston, L. (2013). Museum/gallery conservator job description. Retrieved from http://www.prospects.ac.uk/museum_gallery_conservator_job_description.htm.</ref> Conservation science (sometimes called museum science) aids every aspect of a museum’s mission to study its collections, both inside and out of the laboratory.<ref name="Neuman2011" /> * Maintaining full conservation records by documenting the condition of an object or site, including any previous restoration work and to outline treatment methods and materials in detail.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Documentation ensures the careful recording of treatment procedures and materials so there can be no misunderstanding in the future about what is part of the original work of art and what has been added or altered by the conservator<ref name="Neuman2011" /> * Producing a visual record of the object for identification purposes and to illustrate its condition.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> The examination of the object, treatment proposal, and the actual treatment is documented with written reports and photographs<ref name="Landry2000" /> * Monitoring and recording display and storage conditions with the aim of keeping objects in a stable condition.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Preservation is the ultimate goal of conservation. By taking into account the possible day-to-day stresses caused by an object’s environment, museum conservators do their best to preserve art for generations to come.<ref name="Neuman2011" /> * Proposing and estimating the costs of treatments to halt decay and stabilize an artifact.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Conservators, present a proposal for work to be done as well as a report on the completion of the treatment.<ref name="Landry2000" /> * Restoration to bring a deteriorated or damaged object or structure closer to a previous or assumed appearance or function.<ref name="Careers2014" /> Although conservators cannot exactly recapture the original appearance, they are able to make highly educated decisions about how to restore an object if they identify the materials from which it was made and fully understand their properties.<ref name="Neuman2011" /> * Organizing the logistics of long-term projects and collaborating with other conservators.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> This collaboration can take place when items are on loan or when outside help is needed for complex conservation projects. * Working out creative solutions to clean, support and repair sensitive objects.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Ultimately, just as every object is unique, every conservation decision must be considered on its own and on a case-by-case basis.<ref name="Neuman2011" /> * Developing and maintaining appropriate standards within the specialist area.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Critical information can be lost and an object permanently damaged when things are cared for without basic guidelines and information.<ref name="Landry2000" /> * Keeping up to date with the latest conservation techniques and practices, through research and training.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Conservation is a young profession, which means it continues to evolve over time and conservators must be able to keep up to date with the latest trends. * Advising on procedures for the safe exhibition and travel of cultural materials . Museum conservators strive to maintain the integrity of each work of art throughout its life, whenever it is handled, stored, displayed, or shipped to other locations for exhibitions.<ref name="Neuman2011" /> * Direct and supervise curatorial, technical, and student staff in the handling, mounting, care, and storage of art objects.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> Other museum departments look to conservators and restorers for direction on safety procedures when it comes to objects in the museum's collection. * Recommend preservation procedures, such as control of temperature and humidity, to curatorial and building staff.<ref name="Johnston2013" /> The most important step you can take to ensure the preservation of any collection is to create a safe display and storage environment that will not cause further deterioration of the objects.<ref name="Landry2000" />
[[File:Russian-museum-conservation-department-092.jpg|thumb|Russian-museum-conservation-department-092]]
== Knowledge and skills == * Working knowledge of the vocabulary of conservation and scientific methodology in order to effectively examine an object, assess its state, understand its history, and articulate its needs.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Must have a firm grasp of philosophical precepts expressed in the AIC Code of Ethics and Guidelines for Practice in order to formulate a treatment.<ref name="Defining2003" /> The conservator must understand that it’s important to respect the integrity of the object and that his or her actions should not jeopardize the long-term preservation of the object. * Understanding and appreciation of the aesthetic, cultural, economic, historical, political, religious, scientific, and social values of objects, buildings and sites.<ref name="Defining2003" /> This understanding and appreciation are critically important when devising preservation and conservation plans, strategies, and treatments. * Working knowledge of how materials constituting cultural heritage were acquired, modified, processed, or manufactured and how craft or manufacturing techniques and processes have evolved through time.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Possess knowledge of the chemical and physical properties and long-term behavior of a wide range of materials and whether these materials were used in the original fabrication of an object or in its subsequent treatment and preservation.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Must be aware of issues that arise from the ways that culturally significant materials will be accessed or used by society.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Knowledge of the context in which cultural heritage is used, as context may be critically important to understanding its condition, formulating appropriate treatment and recommending future care.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Knowledgeable about safety in the workplace and must carry out his or her practice in compliance with federal, state, and logical regulations.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Working knowledge of scientific principles as they apply to conservation, including how to access and use scientific literature and how to assess the validity of published research in conservation and allied fields.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Ability to recognize and understand the changes that occur in cultural heritage over time and be able to distinguish the cause of the changes (natural, chemical, physical, biological, or by human influence).<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Versed in the many ways in which light, relative humidity, temperature, and pollutants can influence the long-term preservation of cultural heritage and must be familiar with techniques, equipment, and resources that can assist in managing these important environmental factors<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Ability to conduct a safe, thorough examination of cultural materials in order to gather relevant information about their condition and to formulate an appropriate plan for preservation and treatment.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Know which tools and techniques are appropriate, how extensive the examination should be, and how or whether to perform external, intrusive, and occasionally destructive sampling.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Understand the purposes of documentation and must be knowledgeable and proficient in appropriate methods of written and pictorial documentation as well as in the maintenance and preservation of the body of information produced during examination and treatment.<ref name="Defining2003" /> * Awareness of various treatment methods available as well as their effects on different types of cultural heritage, based on an understanding of condition, natural use, cultural, historic, and scientific significance, and, if applicable, the artist’s or maker’s intent.<ref name="Defining2003" />
== Education and training ==
=== Undergraduate and graduate education === Conservators can receive training through apprenticeships, internships and graduate programs. In order to be accepted into a graduate program, they will need to fulfill some undergraduate prerequisites. This includes undergraduate coursework in science, the humanities (art history, anthropology, and archaeology), and studio art.<ref name="Careers2014" /> Some graduate programs may also require internship, volunteer, apprenticeship, or paid conservation experience.<ref name="Careers2014" /> Many may also require a personal interview where candidates are asked to present a portfolio of art and conservation project work that demonstrates manual dexterity and familiarity with techniques and materials.<ref name="Careers2014" /> Graduate programs generally require two to four years of study, which can also include a full-time internship in the final year where students work under the guidance of experienced conservators.<ref name="Careers2014" /> There are also a limited number of Ph.D. programs for advanced study in conservation.<ref name="Careers2014" /> Conservation-related programs are described on the websites of the AIC,<ref>"[http://www.conservation-us.org/jobs/become-a-conservator#.WSycysm1tPt Careers in Conservation: Become a Conservator]". American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC). www.conservation-us.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> the National Council for Preservation Education (NCPE)],<ref>"[http://www.ncpe.us/program-list/ Academic Programs]". National Council for Preservation Education (NCPE). www.ncpe.us. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> and the [[Society of American Archivists (SAA)]].<ref>"[http://www2.archivists.org/dae Directory of Archival Education]". Society of American Archivists (SAA). www.archivists.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref>
=== Post-graduate fellowships === Post-graduate fellowships have also been cited as valuable experiences in their professional development.<ref name="Careers2014" /> These fellowships provide intensive research, practice, and exposure to diverse professional staff or significant collections.<ref name="Careers2014" /> A few institutions that offer fellowships include the [[Getty Foundation]],<ref>"[http://www.getty.edu/foundation/initiatives/current/gradinterns/ Graduate Internships]". The Getty Foundation. www.getty.edu. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> the [[Museum Conservation Institute|Smithsonian's Museum Conservation Institute]],<ref>"[http://www.si.edu/mci/english/professional_development/fellowships_internships.html Fellowships & Internships]". Smithsonian Museum Conservation Institute. www.si.edu/mci. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> and the Straus Center of [[Harvard Art Museums]].<ref>"[http://www.harvardartmuseums.org/teaching-and-research/research-centers/straus-center-for-conservation-and-technical-studies Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies]". Harvard Art Museums. www.harvardartmuseums.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref>
=== Continued professional development === The specialty of conservation is ever-changing and evolving, which means that practicing conservators must stay up-to-date of advances in technology and methodology.<ref name="Careers2014" /> Conservators usually expand their knowledge through reading publications, attending professional meetings, and enrolling in short-term workshops or courses.<ref name="Careers2014" /> AIC offers many workshops, conferences, and online courses and tutorials.<ref>"[http://www.conservation-us.org/courses#.WSykcMm1tPt Professional Development Courses in Conservation Education]". American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC). www.conservation-us.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> Conservation OnLine (CoOL) also offers resources for conservation professionals.<ref>"[http://cool.conservation-us.org/ Welcome to CoOL]". Conservation OnLine (CoOL). cool.conservation-us.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref>
== Areas of specialty == Some conservators specialize in a particular material or group of objects, such as archaeology, ceramics and glass, furniture and wood, gilding and decorative surfaces, historic interiors, metals, paintings, paper and books, photographic materials, stained glass, stone and wall paintings, textiles, sculptures, and architecture.<ref name="Careers2014" /><ref name="Johnston2013" />
*[[Archaeological conservation]] *[[Architectural conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of books, manuscripts, documents and ephemera|Books, manuscripts, and documentation conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of ceramic objects|Ceramic conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of glass objects|Glass conservation]] *[[Historic garden conservation]] *[[Historic preservation|Historic Site conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of ivory objects|Ivory conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of metals|Metal conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of musical instruments|Musical instrument conservation]] *[[Paintings conservator|Painting conservation]] *[[Conservator of photographs|Photograph conservation]] *[[Textile conservator|Textile conservation]] *[[Conservation and restoration of wooden furniture|Wooden furniture conservation]]
[[File:Ceramics conservation.jpg|thumb|Ceramics conservation]]
== Ethics == The primary goal for conservators and restorers is the preservation of cultural property. In order to achieve this goal, conservators abide by a code of ethics and guidelines that establish the principles that guide conservation professionals and others who are involved in the care of cultural property. An example of a code of ethics and guidelines for practice were created by the [[American Institute for Conservation|American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC)]].<ref>"[http://www.conservation-us.org/about-us/core-documents/code-of-ethics#.VPPM0saLTwM Code of Ethics and Guidelines for Practive]" (2015). American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC). www.conservation-us.org. Retrieved 2017-05-29.</ref> One of the most important principles in a conservator's code of ethics is that treatments should be reversible, which means that one must be able to undo any treatment in the future.<ref name="Neuman2011" /> Conservators strive to only minimize interventions and not completely alter an object during restoration. Conservation focuses on the material aspects of art, and respect for original materials remains a crucial element of the field's ethics.<ref name="Neuman2011" />
== Professional organizations == *[http://www.conservation-us.org/ American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC)] *[http://www.ica-artconservation.org/ Art Conservation] *[http://www.aiccm.org.au/ The Australian Institute for the Conservation of Cultural Material (AICCM)] *[http://www.icom-cc.org/ International Council of Museums – Committee for Conservation(ICOM-CC)] *[https://www.iiconservation.org/ International Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (ICC)] *[http://canada.pch.gc.ca/eng/1454704828075 Canadian Conservation Institute] *[https://www.cac-accr.ca/home Canadian Association for Conservation (CAC)] *[https://www.icon.org.uk Institute of Conservation (UK)]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://www.britishmuseum.org/about_us/departments/conservation_and_science.aspx British Museum Conservation] *[http://www.metmuseum.org/research/conservation-and-scientific-research Metropolitan Museum of Art Conservation] *[http://www.mfa.org/collections/conservation-and-collections-management Museum of Fine Arts Conservation] *[http://www.onetonline.org/link/summary/25-4013.00 O-NET OnLine Summary Report for Museum Technicians and Conservators] *[http://www.si.edu/mci/index.html Smithsonian Museum Conservation] *[http://canada.pch.gc.ca/eng/1454704828075 Canadian Conservation Institute] *[http://spotlightoncareers.org/career/museums/ Spotlight on Careers: Museums] *[http://www.icom-cc.org/47/about-icom-cc/definition-of-profession/#.VTW7d2aLRm4 The Conservator-Restorer: A Definition of the Profession] *[https://www.sokanu.com/careers/museum-conservator/ What does a Museum Conservator do?]
