{{Infobox dot-com company |name = HomeSeer |logo = HomeSeer_Company_Logo.png |url = {{URL|homeseer.com}} |type = [[Privately held company|Private]] |products = Home automation software
Home automation controllers
[[Z-Wave]] controllers
Z-Wave light switches
Z-Wave water valves
Z-Wave sensors |founder = Richard Helmke |location = [[Bedford, New Hampshire]] |area_served = Worldwide |industry = [[Home automation]] |language = [[English (language)|English]] |founded = {{start date|1999}} }} '''HomeSeer Technologies LLC''' is a technology company based in [[Bedford, New Hampshire]], in the United States. HomeSeer makes [[home automation]] controllers and software, designed to integrate lighting, [[HVAC]], security, [[Audiovisual|AV]] and other subsystems in most homes. Additionally, the company maintains an online store of compatible home automation products and a free online community [[Internet forum|forum]] for users and dealers. == History == ===1999-2004=== [[File:HomeSeer_HS1_CD_Media.png|thumb|HS1 v1.7 distribution CD from 2004.]] HomeSeer was founded in 1999 by company president Richard Helmke. At the time, Helmke was employed as Software Project Leader for [[Cabletron Systems|Cabletron]] (later becoming [[Enterasys Networks|Enterasys]]) in [[Rochester, New Hampshire]]. Helmke developed an interest in home automation and set about to find a software program that would fit his needs. After trying several programs, Helmke elected to create his own program (initially named ''AutoHome''), and launched that effort, as a part-time pursuit, under the company name "Keware". Shortly after release, Keware was renamed ''HomeSeer'' and AutoHome was renamed ''HomeSeer v1'' or ''HS1'' for short. At first, the software was compatible with [[X10 (industry standard)|X10]] light switches, plug-in modules and controllers. Over time, support was added for additional products such as the ADI Ocelot, JDS Stargate controller and WGL W800 wireless receivers. An open [[API]] coupled with a freely available [[Software development kit|SDK]] was added to encourage 3rd party development of plug-in (drivers) for support of additional technologies and products. HS1 included support for remote internet access and voice control using [[Microsoft Speech API|Microsoft speech technology (SAPI)]].{{cite web| url=http://www.chron.com/news/article/Working-Home-2016743.php| title=Simple, low-cost automation kit turns lights on when nobody's home |publisher=Houston Chronicle| last=Currid| first=Cheryl| date=16 August 2001| accessdate=4 January 2016}} As sales of HS1 increased, a message board forum was implemented to provide community-based support for HS1 users. In 2002, Helmke left his position at Enterasys to focus solely on HomeSeer. In 2003, driver support was added to HS1 for [[Z-Wave]], a wireless [[Mesh networking|mesh network]] technology. At that time, the technology was in its infancy with only a handful of lighting products available from ''Advanced Control Technologies''{{cite web|url=http://products.z-wavealliance.org/Search/DoAdvancedSearch?regionId=2&category=-1&manufacturer=13|title=Z-Wave Product Catalog|publisher=Z-Wave Alliance|accessdate=8 January 2016}} and [[Osram Sylvania|Sylvania]]. As of 2015, the [[Z-Wave|Z-Wave Alliance]] reported there were more than 1,400 Z-Wave certified products{{cite web|url=http://z-wavealliance.org/z-wave-pavilion-promotes-robust-smart-home-ecosystem-to-installer-community-at-cedia-expo/|title=Z-Wave Pavilion Promotes Robust Smart Home Ecosystem to Installer Community at CEDIA EXPO.|publisher=[[Z-Wave|Z-Wave Alliance]]|accessdate=24 November 2015}} including light switches, thermostats, door locks, water valves, garage door controllers, sensors and other products. In 2004, HomeSeer released its first hardware product, the ''ZU0100-001'' Z-Wave USB interface. This product functioned as a Z-Wave [[transceiver]] to allow HS1 software to communicate with wireless Z-Wave devices. ===2005-2010=== August 2005 marked the release of HS2 software. The new version was designed as a [[web application]] to allow for remote set up and configuration, as well as remote control. A professional version (HSPRO) targeting custom installers and featuring advanced Z-Wave support with pre-licensed plug-ins, was also released. In December, the company's first hardware controller (PRO-100) was released.{{cite web|url=http://www.crn.com/reviews/channel-programs/189501102/review-homeseers-home-controller-gets-smarter.htm|title=Review: HomeSeer's Home Controller Gets Smarter|publisher=CRN|last=Morejon|first=Mario|accessdate=25 November 2015}} The PRO-100 was a [[Mechanical fan|fan-less]] design with [[Solid-state drive#DOM|DOM]] storage that included an embedded installation of HSPRO software. In 2006, HomeSeer released the ''Z-Troller'', a handheld Z-Wave network controller that doubled as a Z-Wave interface. Since Z-Troller was both a network controller ''and'' interface, it supported advanced features such as network optimization and network backup and restore. In October, the PRO-100 was upgraded to a faster Series II model.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2006/10/28/homeseer-announces-pro-100-series-ii-home-automation-controller/|title=HomeSeer announces PRO-100 Series-II home automation controller|publisher=Engadget|last=Murph|first=Darren|accessdate=26 November 2015}} In 2007, HomeSeer released the ''HSM100'', a battery operated Z-Wave 'multisensor' with built-in sensors for [[Motion detector|motion]], [[Thermometer|temperature]] and [[Photodetector|light level]]. The HSM100 was well suited for home automation ''events'' that relied on some combination of its sensor data. HomeSeer's ''HomeTroller'' was also released in 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/press_release_homeseer_unveils_new_hometroller_home_automation_controller/ |title=HomeSeer Unveils New HomeTroller Home Automation Controller |publisher=CEPro.com |accessdate=25 November 2015 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} to provide functionality similar to the PRO-100 but at a lower price point. Unlike the PRO-100, the original HomeTroller was equipped with a conventional mechanical hard drive, active cooling (with fans) and embedded HS2 software. Subsequent versions were released with passive cooling (no fans) and with DOM, [[Secure Digital|SD Card]] or [[SSD]] storage to improve reliability. In 2009, HomeSeer released its first [[mobile app]], a software program called ''HSTouch''. Originally developed for [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] [[iOS]] platform, HSTouch gave HomeSeer users the ability to monitor and control their homes with their [[iPhone]]s and [[iPod]]s. A companion program, ''HSTouch Designer'', was also released for those who wished to customize the mobile app with their own screen designs and graphics. In 2010, HomeSeer released its [[Android (operating system)|Android]] version of HSTouch mobile app.{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/homeseer_hstouch_android_app/|title=HomeSeer is putting customized HSTouch control into the palm of Android users.|publisher=CEPro|last=Cericola|first=Rachel|accessdate=26 November 2015}} In September, HomeTroller was upgraded to the S3 model.{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/homeseer_exploits_rise_of_android_fall_of_charmed_quark/|title=HomeSeer Exploits Rise of Android, Fall of Charmed Quark|publisher=CEPro|last=Jacobson|first=Julie|accessdate=28 November 2015}} ===2011-2013=== [[File:HomeTroller-SE_Home_Controller.png|thumb|HomeTroller-SE was in production from 2011-2014]] In 2011, HomeSeer released the HomeTroller-SE{{cite web|url=http://www.automatedhome.co.uk/reviews/homeseer-hometroller-se-pro-home-automation-controller-review.html|title=HomeSeer Hometroller SE-Pro Home Automation Controller Review|publisher=Automated Home|last=Watt|first=Ken|accessdate=4 December 2015}} as its new entry level controller. The -SE model featured a less powerful [[CPU]] and fewer features than the standard HomeTroller model but at approximately half the cost. An even lower cost ''HomeTroller-Mini'' was also in the works with a prototype unit debuting at CES 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/01/07/homeseer-hometroller-mini-home-automation-controller-gets-you-on/|title=HomeSeer HomeTroller-Mini home automation controller gets you one step closer to the bachelor pad of the future|publisher=Engadget|last=Trout|first=Christopher|accessdate=26 November 2015}} However, the HomeTroller-Mini design was later abandoned before release because of parts availability and cost issues. In 2013, HomeSeer released HS3, a significant upgrade to the HS2 version. HS3 included an all-new [[JQuery UI|JQuery]] web [[GUI]], redesigned automation 'engine', multi-network Z-Wave support and new counter and timer features. A professional version, ''HS3PRO'', was also released to service the dealer channel. HomeSeer's HomeTroller Zee was also released in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/homeseer_debuts_its_smallest_cheapest_home_automation_hub/|title=HomeSeer Debuts its Smallest, Cheapest Home Automation Hub|publisher=CEPro|last=Jacobson|first=Julie|accessdate=26 November 2015}} The Zee was based on the [[Raspberry Pi|Raspberry Pi1 model B computer]], included HS3 software and was bundled with an [[Aeon Labs]] Z-Stick Z-Wave interface. HomeTroller Zee replaced the HomeTroller-SE as the company's entry level home controller. ===2014=== In January 2014, HomeSeer introduced voice programming and automatic camera support{{cite web|url=http://cocoontech.com/forums/page/articles/_/news/events/ces-2014-exclusive-update-homeseer-technologies-r781|title=CES 2014: Exclusive Update - HomeSeer Technologies|publisher=Cocoontech|last=Lavelle|first=Morgan|accessdate=15 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/homeseer_adds_camera_voice_support_to_hometroller_zee/|title=HomeSeer Adds Camera, Voice Support to HomeTroller Zee|publisher=CEPro|last=Cericola|first=Rachel|accessdate=15 December 2015}} for their controllers. Voice programming allowed users to create automation events solely by voice using any Android mobile device. Automatic camera support was designed to automatically detect and configure settings for [[Foscam]] brand IP cameras. This allowed the cameras to be viewed with the HSTouch mobile app. In March, HomeSeer released the model WFTT07 ''Control Pad'' free-standing 7" Android tabletop [[touchscreen]] embedded with their HSTouch mobile app.{{cite web|url=http://www.electronichouse.com/daily/smart-home/homeseer-makes-a-tabletop-touchscreen-for-android-users/|title=HomeSeer Makes a Tabletop Smart Home Touchscreen for Android Users|publisher=Electronic House|last=Cericola|first=Rachel|accessdate=25 November 2015}} The unit was designed to function as a WiFi connected control [[Web portal|portal]] for HomeSeer controllers. In April, HomeSeer launched ''MyHomeSeer-Remote'' (''MyHS'') remote access web service for HS3.{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/homeseer_adds_cloud_service_to_home_automation_system/|title=HomeSeer Adds Cloud Service to Home Automation System|publisher=CEPro|last=Jacobson|first=Julie|accessdate=26 November 2015}} MyHS simplified the process of enabling remote access to HomeSeer systems by eliminating the need to adjust [[Router (computing)|router]] settings or use [[DDNS]] technology. MyHS was also designed to optimize connection performance in the home by automatically providing a direct [[Local area network|LAN]] connection for users attempting to access their systems on the local [[Subnetwork|sub-net]]. In September, HomeSeer released their ''HomeTroller-SEL'' to replace the HomeTroller-SE as the company's mid-level controller.{{cite web|url=http://www.electronichouse.com/daily/smart-home/homeseer-makes-new-hometroller-sel-home-controller-faster-and-more-affordab/|title=HomeSeer Makes New HomeTroller-SEL Home Controller Faster and More Affordable|publisher=Electronic House|last=Cericola|first=Rachel|accessdate=25 November 2015}} Compared to the [[Windows XP|WindowsXP]]-based SE, the new SEL model included a faster CPU, twice the [[Random-access memory|RAM]] and SSD storage, all running on a [[Debian]] distribution of [[Linux]]. Also in September, HomeSeer released their ''A2Z-Link'' Z-Wave bridge module and the ''HSM200'' Z-Wave multi-sensor.{{cite web|url=http://www.electronichouse.com/daily/smart-home/homeseer-puts-z-wave-into-2-new-home-automation-products/|title=HomeSeer Puts Z-Wave into 2 New Home Automation Products|publisher=Electronic House|last=Cericola|first=Rachel|accessdate=25 November 2015}} * The A2Z-Link module was similar in design to the HomeTroller Zee but also included a newly developed [[Communications protocol|protocol]] to allow other controller manufacturers to communicate with Z-Wave devices using simple [[JSON]] or [[ASCII]] commands. A2Z-Link was conceived as an [[Original equipment manufacturer|OEM]] product; not intended for direct to consumer sales. * The new HSM200 was [[Mains electricity|line-powered]], allowing the unit to function as a Z-Wave [[repeater]]. HSM200 also included an [[RGB color model|RGB]] [[LED]] indicator that could be controlled by HomeSeer systems to change colors when things happened in the home. In November, the HomeTroller S6 becomes HomeSeer's new [[flagship]] home controller,{{cite web|url=http://www.electronichouse.com/daily/smart-home/homeseer-promises-efficient-home-automation-with-hometroller-s6/|title=HomeSeer Promises Efficient Home Automation with HomeTroller S6|publisher=Electronic House|accessdate=26 November 2015}} replacing the PRO-100. ===2015=== In January 2015, HomeSeer released the Z-NET,{{cite web|url=http://www.electronichouse.com/daily/smart-home/homeseer-z-net-can-combine-232-z-wave-home-automation-devices/|title=HomeSeer Z-NET Can Combine Up to 232 Z-Wave Home Automation Devices|publisher=Electronic House|last=Rachel|first=Cericola|accessdate=15 December 2015}} an [[Internet Protocol|IP-enabled]] remote Z-Wave interface for use with its HS3-based systems. Since Z-NET works over a network connection, it can be placed nearly anywhere in the home and may also be used in outbuildings, vacation homes or other secondary residences. In April, HomeSeer launched its [[IFTTT]] channel.{{cite web|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/enabling_richer_home_automation_through_limited_ifttt_smart_home_engine/|title=Enabling Richer Home Automation Through IFTTT Smart-Home Engine|publisher=CEPro|last=Jacobson|first=Julie|accessdate=18 December 2015}} IFTTT is a web service that allows users to create ''recipes'' that connect products, services and apps from more than 200 different companies around the world. The principal benefit of launching the channel is that it provides web-based integration for products, services and apps for which there are no native HomeSeer drivers (plug-ins). For example, a HomeSeer/IFTTT user could activate the [[ESPN]] sports network IFTTT channel and create a recipe to launch a HomeSeer event to turn on their TV and speak an alert when a sporting event begins. In May, HomeSeer released its HomeTroller Zee S2 controller, based on the Raspberry Pi2 computer. Compared to the original Zee, the S2 model included a faster CPU, had twice the RAM and it included an internal [[Sigma Designs|Sigma]] 500 series Z-Wave module for native Z-Wave support. At the same time, several HomeSeer products underwent and achieved [http://z-wavealliance.org/z-wave_plus_certification/ Z-Wave Plus certification]. These products included HS3 software, HomeTroller Zee S2, HomeTroller-SEL, HomeTroller S6, Z-NET, SmartStick+ and A2Z-Link. In December, HomeSeer released its Skill (app) for the [[Amazon Echo]]. The Skill allows HomeSeer users to control their systems by voice using the Amazon Echo. ===2016=== In March 2016, HomeSeer released a line of Z-Wave Plus lighting products.{{cite web|url=http://www.twice.com/news/home-automation/homeseer-adds-z-wave-plus-products/60922|title=HomeSeer Adds Z-Wave Plus Products|publisher=Twice.com|last=Palenchar|first=Joseph|accessdate=1 May 2016}} The line included the HS-WS100+ wall switch, HS-WD100+ wall dimmer, HS-WA100+ wall accessory (for 3-way circuits), HS-PD100+ lamp module, HS-PA100+ appliance module and HS-DTA19+ smart light bulb. == Compatible Technologies & Products == Software is at the core of every system produced by HomeSeer. It's licensed as a stand-alone product (HS3) for users who wish to run it on their own personal computers. It's also pre-installed onto HomeTroller controllers, for users who prefer a more fully configured solution. In a typical installation, HS3 systems are connected to the users home network and may be programmed with any web browser. Once programming is complete, the HS3 system will carry out automation functions unattended. If desired, the HSTouch mobile app may be used to monitor and manually control the products in the home. HomeSeer's MyHS web service is designed to provide remote internet access only and is not required for processing of automation events in the home. HomeSeer systems are designed to integrate with the following technologies and products using a mixture of native and 3rd-party drivers (plug-ins): ===Compatible technologies=== * [[Z-Wave]] * [[Zigbee]] * [[Insteon]] * [[Universal powerline bus|UPB]] * [[X10 (industry standard)|X10]] * [[PLCBUS]] * [[IFTTT]] * [[Amazon Echo]] * [[Google Home]] * [[PAL Home Automation]] A complete listing of compatible technologies may be found on HomeSeer's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.homeseer.com/homeseer-plug-ins.html|title=HomeSeer Plug-ins|accessdate=31 December 2015}} ===Compatible products=== * [[Light switch]]es and plug-in modules * [[Thermostat]]s * [[Lock (security device)|Door Locks]] * [[Garage door opener|Garage door controllers]] * [[Valve|Water valves]] * [[Security alarm|Security systems]] * TVs, [[AV receiver|Audio/Video receivers]] and related products * [[IP camera|IP Video Cameras]] * Environmental & security sensors A complete listing of compatible products may be found on HomeSeer's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.homeseer.com/compatible-products.html|title=HomeSeer Compatible Products|accessdate=31 December 2015}} == Recognition, awards and reviews == {{unordered list |''TheWireCutter.com'' ranks HomeSeer HS-WD100+ as the Best Z-Wave In-Wall Dimmer.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/06/02/the-best-z-wave-in-wall-dimmer/|title=The Best Z-Wave In-Wall Dimmer|last=Cericola|first=Rachel|publisher=The Wire Cutter|accessdate=11 October 2016}} |''[[Inc. A '''hype man''', in [[hip hop music]] and [[rapping]], is a backup rapper and/or singer who supports the primary rappers with exclamations and interjections and who attempts to increase the audience's excitement with call-and-response chants.<ref name=Hilltop>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehilltoponline.com/life-style/the-role-of-the-hype-man-in-hip-hop-1.464291 |title=The Hilltop - The Role of The 'Hype Man' In Hip-Hop |publisher=Thehilltoponline.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717003938/http://www.thehilltoponline.com/life-style/the-role-of-the-hype-man-in-hip-hop-1.464291 |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>Barrett, Grant, 2006, ''The Official Dictionary of Unofficial English'', McGraw-Hill Professional, p. 182.</ref><ref>Hip Hop: An Encyclopedia of the Movement, Music, and Culture, Greenwood Publishing Group, p. 176.</ref><ref>Edwards, Paul, 2009, How to Rap: The Art & Science of the Hip-Hop MC, Chicago Review Press, p. 304.</ref><ref>"Kool Moe Dee". Thafoundation.com. Retrieved 2010-08-12.</ref><ref>"Record Executives Thought Jay-Z Was No Good » MTV Newsroom". Newsroom.mtv.com. 2009-08-26. Retrieved 2010-08-12.</ref> Music writer Mickey Hess expands the term as follows: "a hype man is a figure who plays a central but supporting role within a group, making his own interventions, generally aimed at hyping up the crowd while also drawing attention to the words of the [[Master_of_ceremonies#Hip_hop|MC]]".<ref name=IconsofHipHop>Hess, Mickey, 2007, ''Icons of Hip Hop: An Encyclopedia of the Movement, Music, and Culture'', Greenwood Publishing Group, p. 176.</ref>
Discussing the role of the hype man in the book ''[[How to Rap]]'', [[Royce da 5'9"]] describes how a hype man can contribute to a live performance: "a lot of my verses [can] be so constant with the flow [that] I'd need somebody to help me."<ref name="autogenerated304">Edwards, Paul, 2009, ''[[How to Rap]]: The Art & Science of the Hip-Hop MC'', Chicago Review Press, p. 304.</ref> [[Lateef the Truthspeaker|Lateef]] has stated, "You're gonna have to have somebody say something somewhere to give you a breath... usually it's just a matter of getting somebody to hit some line or some word in a line—that's all you really need."<ref name="autogenerated304"/>
==Origins== Early [[hip hop]] hype men included Cowboy and Creole of [[Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five]].<ref name= Hilltop/><ref name=IconsofHipHop/> [[Kool Moe Dee]] calls Creole “the original hype man”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thafoundation.com/moedee.htm |title=Kool Moe Dee |publisher=Thafoundation.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref> [[File:Public Enemy 4.jpg|thumb|right|American rapper [[Flavor Flav]] hyping up a crowd in May 2008]] The quintessential hype man, for many fans and musicians of the era, was [[Public Enemy (group)|Public Enemy]]'s hype man [[Flavor Flav]], whose exuberant approach to the art in the group's recordings and videos made him, arguably, the first household-name hype man, a figure more famous than many MCs. He established many of the conventions of the craft, such as an outlandish sense of style (epitomized by his wearing of large clocks around his neck) and a vocal style that contrasted dramatically with that of the MC (his rasping high voice was a counterpoint to [[Chuck D]]'s booming baritone). [[File:Hype-Man Relione with Chef Sean .jpg|thumb|right|Hype man Relione (right) performing with rapper Chef Sean]] [[Jay-Z]] began his career as a hype man for [[Jaz-O]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2009/08/26/jay-z-record-executives/ |title=Record Executives Thought Jay-Z Was No Good » MTV Newsroom |publisher=Newsroom.mtv.com |date=2009-08-26 |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref><ref>Vibe magazine, Jan 2004, Vol. 12, No. 1, published by Vibe Media Group, p. 75.</ref> and was later the hype man for [[Big Daddy Kane]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Jonathan Cunningham |url=http://www.browardpalmbeach.com/2007-03-15/music/kane-s-domain |title=Kane's Domain - Page 1 - Music - Broward/Palm Beach - Broward-Palm Beach New Times |publisher=Broward/Palm Beach |date=2007-03-15 |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref>
==Examples==<!-- DO NOT ADD MORE WITHOUT RELIABLE CITATIONS -->
Examples of hype men include [[Freaky Tah]] of the [[The Lost Boyz|Lost Boyz]], [[Memphis Bleek]] for [[Jay-Z]], and [[Proof (rapper)|Proof]] and [[Mr. Porter]] of [[D12]] for [[Eminem]].<ref name="IconsofHipHop" /> ''Icons of Hip Hop'' also notes that some producers, such as [[Sean Combs|Diddy]], [[Lil Jon]], [[Swizz Beatz]], and [[Jermaine Dupri]], "have transitioned from a hype man role to become [[rapper]]s and stars in their own right".<ref name="IconsofHipHop" />
Occasionally pop groups include a member up front alongside the lead singer who may perform backup vocals or percussion but largely functions to excite the audience through dancing and/or stage patter. Examples include [[Bob Nastanovich]] for [[Pavement (band)|Pavement]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grantland.com/features/indie-rock-legend-bob-nastanovich-pavement-silver-jews-horse-racing/|title='It Hasn't Been a Disaster: Indie-rock legend Bob Nastanovich on Pavement, the Silver Jews, and horse racing. But not in that order.|date=2012-06-20|author=Alex Pappademas|accessdate=2017-01-22}}</ref> and [[Guy Picciotto]] for [[Fugazi]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Nathan Leigh |url=http://afropunk.com/2011/05/public-enemy-the-forgotten-innovators-of-post-hardcore/ |title=Public Enemy: The Forgotten Innovators of Post-Hardcore |date=2011-05-18 |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Zasuul]], a kind of hype man in Mongolian wrestling

{{toc right}} The '''I Look Like an Engineer''' movement was created in August 2015 by software developer [[Isis Anchalee]] (formerly Isis Wenger) as a response to the backlash the [[OneLogin]] recruitment ad in which she was featured received. The movement aspired to break the [[stereotype]]s and promote diversity around [[Minority group|unrepresented groups]], particularly (Women, POC, and LGBTQ+) within the engineering industry. Its primary tactic is the use of the [[hashtag]] #ILookLikeAnEngineer on social media sites such as [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], and [[Instagram]], along with pictures of engineers or engineering students.
The I Look Like an Engineer movement has sparked other similar movements that also seek to break stereotypes in their industry, such as I Look Like a Surgeon,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/surgeon-hashtag-takes-highlighting-women-article-1.2325102|title=‘I Look Like a Surgeon’ hashtag takes off after ‘I Look Like an Engineer’ movement that celebrated women in STEM|website=New York Daily News|publisher=New York Daily News|last1=Engel|first1=Meredith|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref> I Look like a Professor and I Look Like a Civil Engineer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilooklikeacivilengineer.com|title=Diversity in Civil Engineering – I Look Like a Civil Engineer|website=www.ilooklikeacivilengineer.com|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
== OneLogin campaign == In the summer of 2015 [[OneLogin]], a software company in San Francisco created a recruitment campaign aimed at attracting engineers to their home office in San Francisco. Four employees were invited to participate, including Anchalee. The ads were placed in the BART public transit stations and showed several OneLogin engineers sharing their experience working for the company. The ad featuring Anchalee went viral on several social media sites.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-33783007|title=What does an engineer look like?|date=2015-08-05|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/i-look-like-an-engineer_us_55c0be70e4b06363d5a35cfd|title=#ILookLikeAnEngineer Destroys The Tech Nerd Stereotype|last=Fellow|first=Lorenzo Ligato Editorial|last2=Post|first2=The Huffington|date=2015-08-04|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/technology/hashtag-aims-to-break-gender-stereotypes-in-engineering.html|title=Woman Behind #ILookLikeAnEngineer Says Campaign Against Gender Stereotypes Is ‘Long Overdue’|last=Varn|first=Kathryn|date=2015-08-05|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref> A week after the launch of the campaign went viral, OneLogin posted an article on their blog that talked about the importance of diversity, inclusion, and innovation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/we-are-onelogin|title=We are OneLogin - OneLogin|website=OneLogin|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
== Movement beginnings == The [[OneLogin]] recruitment ad featuring Isis Anchalee went viral as her particular ad received comments stating the belief that she was a model and not an actual engineer. Anchalee took to [https://medium.com/the-coffeelicious/you-may-have-seen-my-face-on-bart-8b9561003e0f#.o1j97etct social media] where she posted a picture of herself holding a piece of paper describing her job and a caption with the hashtag, #ILookLikeanEngineer. In her post she stated her belief that it is important to raise awareness in tech diversity and break the stereotypes of what an engineer should look like.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lien|first1=Tracy|title=Think you know what an engineer looks like? #ilooklikeanengineer says think again|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-i-look-like-an-engineer-20150804-story.html|website=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tyler|first1=Carolyn|title=BAY AREA WOMAN CHALLENGES ENGINEER STEREOTYPES IN NEW AD CAMPAIGN|url=http://abc7news.com/technology/bay-area-woman-challenges-engineer-stereotypes-in-campaign/905064/|website=[[ABC 7 News]]|publisher=ABC|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref>
Her post started the hashtag trend and the hashtag was used 86,000 times by August 7, 2015. The hashtag has been used in approximately 50 countries. The hashtag is mainly used by women and LGBTQ engineers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tan|first1=Avianne|title=ILookLikeAnEngineer Campaign Expands From Twitter to Billboard in Fight Against Stereotypes|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/ilooklikeanengineer-campaign-expands-twitter-billboard-fight-stereotypes/story?id=32945366|website=ABC News|publisher=ABC|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Mather|first1=Laura|title=From Awareness to Action: How Technology Can Transform Its Industry's Own Bias Problem|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/laura-mather/technology-bias-problem_b_8009896.html|website=Huffington Post|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/the-coffeelicious/you-may-have-seen-my-face-on-bart-8b9561003e0f|title=You May Have Seen My Face on BART – The Coffeelicious|last=Anchalee|first=Isis|date=2015-08-01|website=Medium|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref> Subsequently, Anchalee put up a now-defunct [http://www.ilooklikeanengineer.com/ webpage] to establish a safe platform for individuals to share their experiences related to diversity issues within tech fields.
== Support == In an effort to make a lasting impact, Michelle Glauser (the spouse of Anchalee co-worker) began a fundraising campaign using [[Indiegogo]] to create billboards with pictures that people had shared on social media using the hashtag #ILookLikeanEngineer. The proceeds were used to put up more billboards to further the I Look Like an Engineer campaign and excess proceeds were used to fund organizations that teach programming to minorities. The fundraiser’s goal was to raise $3,500. The campaigned ended on September 5, 2015 with $47,285 raised.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/let-s-put-up-an-ilooklikeanengineer-billboard#/|title=Let's Put Up An #ILookLikeAnEngineer Billboard|website=Indiegogo|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
Concurrently, an [https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ilooklikeanengineer-community-gathering-tickets-18026391422 #ILookLikeanEngineer community gathering] organized by Michelle Glauser through Eventbrite as part of efforts to continue further the movement was hosted on August 13, 2015 in San Francisco, CA. During the gathering, photographers collected portraits of willing participants for the billboards and as an effort to document the event. The event was sponsored by Segment, [[Rackspace]], [[OneLogin]], and [https://hackbrightacademy.com/ HackBright Academy]. The event included networking, discussions and a Q&A panel which included [https://twitter.com/isisAnchalee Isis Wenger], [https://twitter.com/AliciaMorga Alicia Morga], [https://twitter.com/waynesutton Wayne Sutton], [https://twitter.com/EricaJoy Erica Baker], [https://twitter.com/shaft Leslie Miley], and [https://twitter.com/Itshella_dom Dom DeGuzman].
== Significance == The struggles that women face in the field of engineering have a long-documented history. In the postwar era, female engineering students found themselves in a mixture of conflicting and positive situations that shaped not only their professional experiences but the field itself. Women faced backlash from not just male students and professors who objectified and viewed female engineers as potential girlfriends instead of fellow students, but also from women faculty or older female students who demanded that younger women endured the same struggles they did.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Girls Coming to Tech|last=Bix|first=Amy|publisher=MIT Press|year=2014|isbn=9780262019545|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
The campus and corporate climate did not change until the mid-1970s when companies began to face civil rights pressure to be more inclusive of female engineers. However, even with these radical changes women continued to experience subtle and overt forms of discrimination in the workplace. During the 1970s, organizations like the [[Society of Women Engineers]] (founded in 1952) among others provided women with support and guidance both on college campuses and in the corporate world.<ref name=":0" />
Recognizing the challenges that women faced and continue to face in male-dominated fields raises awareness about the importance of diversity and intersectionality in the field of engineering and other tech fields. Social movements are taking place in online spaces more frequently as the community of users tends to be wider and more diverse. It is here where users can use their own personal experiences and public outcry to start global dialogues that can enact change.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}}

An '''Imieliński-Lipski algebras''' is an extension of [[relational algebra]] onto tables with different types of [[Null (SQL)|null values]]. It is used to operate on relations with incomplete information.
Imieliński-Lipski algebras are defined to satisfy precise conditions for semantically meaningful extension of the usual relational operators, such as projection, selection, union, and join, from operators on relations to operators on relations with various kinds of "null values".
These conditions require that the system be ''safe'' in the sense that no incorrect conclusion is derivable by using a specified subset F of the relational operators; and that it be ''complete'' in the sense that all valid conclusions expressible by relational expressions using operators in F are in fact derivable in this system. For example, it is well known that the 3-valued logic approach to deal with null values, supported treatment of nulls values by [[SQL]] is not complete, see [[Jeffrey Ullman|Ullman]] book.<ref name="Ullman1982">{{cite book|author1=J.D. Ullman|authorlink=Jeffrey Ullman|title=Principles of Database Systems |year=1982|publisher= Computer Science Press, Potomac, MD.|edition=2nd}}</ref> To show this, let T be: {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |+ T= |- ! NAME !! CLASS !! GRADE !! SEMESTER |- | Rohit || Databases || B || Spring |- | Igor || Networks || A || NULL |- |}
Take SQL query Q
<source lang="sql"> Select NAME From T Where CLASS = 'Networks' & SEMESTER = 'Spring' OR GRADE = 'A' & SEMESTER != 'Spring' </source>
SQL query Q will return empty set (no results) under 3-valued semantics currently adopted by all variants of SQL. This is the case because in SQL, NULL is never equal to any constant – in this case, neither to “Spring” nor “Fall” nor “Winter” (if there is Winter semester in this school). NULL=’Spring” will evaluate to MAYBE and so will NULL=’Fall”. The disjunction MAYBE OR MAYBE evaluates to MAYBE (not TRUE). Thus Igor will not be part of the answer (and of course neither will Rohit). But Igor should be returned as the answer.
Indeed, regardless what semester Igor took the Networks class (no matter what was the unknown value of NULL), the selection condition will be true. This “Igor” will be missed by SQL and the SQL answer won’t be complete according to completeness requirements specified in Imieliński, Witold Lipski, 'Incomplete Information in Relational Databases'.<ref name="JACM 1984"/> It is also argued there that 3-valued logic (TRUE, FALSE, MAYBE) can never provide guarantee of complete answer for tables with incomplete information.
Three algebras which satisfy conditions of safety and completeness are defined as Imielinski-Lipski algebras: the [[Relational algebra|Codd-Tables]] algebra, the V-tables algebra and the Conditional tables (C-tables) algebra.
===Codd-tables Algebra===
Codd-tables Algebra is based on the usual Codd's singe NULL values. The table T above is an example of Codd-table. Codd-table algebra supports projection and positive selections only. It is also demonstrated in [IL84 that it is not possible to correctly extend more relational operators over Codd-Tables. For example, such basic operation as join is not extendable over Codd-tables. It is not possible to define selections with Boolean conditions involving negation and preserve completeness. For example, queries like the above query Q cannot be supported. In order to be able to extend more relational operators, more expressive form of null value representation is needed in tables which are called V-table.
===V-Tables Algebra===
V-tables algebra is based on many different ("marked") null values or variables allowed to appear in a table. V-tables allow to show that a value may be unknown but the same for different tuples. For example, in the table below Gaurav and Igor order the same (but unknown) beer in two unknown bars (which may, or may not be different – but remain unknown). Gaurav and Jane frequent the same unknown bad (Y1). Thus, instead one NULL value, we use indexed variables, or ''Skolem constants'' .<ref>{{cite |title= Skolem constants |url=http://www.sds.lcs.mit.edu/spd/larch/LP/glossary/skolem.html }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |- ! DRINKER !! BEER !! BAR |- | Zhihan || Heineken || Cabana |- | Gaurav || X1 || Y1 |- | Igor || X1 || Y2 |- | Jane || Bud || Y1 |- | John || X2 || Y3 |- |}
V-Tables algebra is shown to correctly support projection, positive selection (with no negation occurring in the selection condition), union, and renaming of attributes, which allows for processing arbitrary conjunctive queries. A very desirable property enjoyed by the V-table algebra is that all relational operators on tables are performed in exactly the same way as in the case of the usual relations.
'''Conditional Tables (C-Tables) Algebra'''
Example of conditional table (c-table) is shown below.
{| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |- ! NAME !! CLASS !! GRADE !! SEMESTER !! con |- | Rohit || Databases || B || Spring || true |- | Igor || Networks || A || x || x ='Spring' |- | Igor || Networks || A || x || x !='Spring' |- |}
It has additional column “con” which is a Boolean condition involving variables, null values – same as in V-tables.
<source lang="sql"> Select * From T Where CLASS='Networks' & SEMESTER='Spring' OR GRADE = 'A' & SEMESTER !='Spring' </source>
over the following table c-table
{| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |+ T1= |- ! NAME !! CLASS !! GRADE !! SEMESTER !! con |- | Rohit || Databases || B || Spring || true |- | Igor || Networks || A || x || true |- |}
Conditional Tables algebra, mainly of theoretical interest, supports projection, selection, union, join, and renaming. Under closed world assumption, it can also handle the operator of difference, thus it can support all relational operators.
==History== Imieliński-Lipski algebras were introduced by [[Tomasz Imieliński]] and [[:pl:Witold Lipski (informatyk)|Witold Lipski Jr.]] in 'Incomplete Information in Relational Databases' <ref name="JACM 1984">{{cite journal|first1 =T. | last1=Imieliński | authorlink= Tomasz Imieliński | first2 = W. | last2 = Lipski Jr. | title=Incomplete information in relational databases | journal=[[Journal of the ACM]]|volume=31|issue=4|date= 1984|pages=761–791|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?view_op=view_citation&hl=en&user=fEYp6hEAAAAJ&citation_for_view=fEYp6hEAAAAJ:UxriW0iASnsC }}</ref>

[[File:Systems thinking about the society.svg|thumb|240px|right|Impression of [[systems thinking]] about society<ref>Illustration is made by Marcel Douwe Dekker (2007) based on an own standard and [[Pierre Malotaux]] (1985), "Constructieleer van de menselijke samenwerking", in BB5 Collegedictaat TU Delft, pp. 120-147.</ref>]] [[Systems science]] is the [[interdisciplinary]] field of science surrounding [[systems theory]], [[cybernetics]], the science of [[complex systems]]. It aims to develop interdisciplinary foundations, which are applicable in a variety of areas, such as engineering, biology, medicine and social sciences. Systems science and [[systemics]] are names for all research related to [[systems theory]]. It is defined as an emerging branch of science that studies [[holistic]] systems and tries to develop logical, mathematical, engineering and philosophical paradigms and frameworks in which physical, technological, biological, social, [[cognitive]] and [[metaphysics|metaphysical]] systems can be studied and developed.
This '''list of systems sciences organizations''' gives an overview of global and local [[organization]]s in the field of [[systems science]]. This list shows all kinds of organizations and institutes listed thematically. {{TOC limit|3}} == Awards == * [[Richard E. Bellman Control Heritage Award]] * [[George B. Dantzig Prize]] * [[Donald P. Eckman Award]] * [[IEEE Simon Ramo Medal]]: award for exceptional achievement in systems engineering and systems science * [[John von Neumann Theory Prize]] * [[Rufus Oldenburger Medal]] * [[Turing Award|A. M. Turing Award]] * UKSS Gold Medallists by the United Kingdom Systems Society{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * [[The Hellenic Society for Systemic Studies Medal]]
== Research centers == === General === ==== America ==== * Center for Complex Systems and Brain Sciences: a multi-disciplinary center in Florida Atlantic University founded in 1985{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * [[International Institute for General Systems Studies]] (IIGSS): an American non-profit scholastic organization for studies and education in Systems science in Pennsylvania, USA * International Systems Institute (ISI): a non-profit, public benefit scientific and educational corporation in Carmel, California, USA{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * MIT Institute for Data, Systems and Society (IDSS): MIT research institute dedicated to analyzing complex, high-impact systems in society and to applying analytical methods to address complex social challenges<ref>https://idss.mit.edu/</ref> * [[Mental Research Institute]]: a center for systems theory and psychotherapy located in Palo Alto, California, USA * [[New England Complex Systems Institute]] (NECSI): an independent educational and research institution dedicated to advancing the study of complex systems * [[Santa Fe Institute]] (SFI): a non-profit research institute dedicated to the study of complex systems in Santa Fe, New Mexico, founded in 1984
==== Europe ==== <!--sorted after initials, how about country name ? or something else--> * [[Institut für Unternehmenskybernetik]], Germany * Institute for Complex Systems Simulation, University of Southampton, UK<ref name="Southampton ICSS">[http://www.icss.soton.ac.uk Institute for Complex Systems Simulation]</ref> * [[International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis]] (IIASA): an international non-governmental research organization located in Laxenburg, near Vienna, in Austria * [[Institute for Biocomputation and Physics of Complex Systems]], Spain * [[Max Planck Institute for Dynamics of Complex Technical Systems]], Germany * [[Max Planck Institute for Dynamics and Self-Organization]], Germany
==== Australia ==== * CSIRO Centre for Complex Systems Science<ref>[http://www.csiro.au/org/CSS.html CSIRO.au]</ref> * [[MASCOS]], ARC Centre of Excellence for Mathematics and Statistics of Complex Systems * [[ARC Centre for Complex Systems]] (ACCS) * Centre for Complex Systems, The University of Sydney<ref>http://sydney.edu.au/complex-systems/</ref>
==== Asia ==== * Center of Excellence in Systems Science, [[IIT Jodhpur]]<ref>[http://www.iitj.ac.in/ss Center of Excellence in Systems Science, IIT Jodhpur] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130529032809/http://www.iitj.ac.in/ss/ |date=2013-05-29 }}</ref>
=== [[Systems biology]] === * [[Department of Systems Biology]] * [[Institute for Systems Biology]] * [[Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics]]
=== [[Systems ecology]] === * [[ETH Zurich]], Terrestrial Systems Ecology<ref>[http://www.sysecol.ethz.ch/ [[ETH Zurich]] Terrestrial Systems Ecology]</ref> * [[University of Amsterdam]], Systems Ecology Department<ref>[http://www.falw.vu.nl/Onderzoeksinstituten/index.cfm/home_subsection.cfm/subsectionid/55B99586-E22B-4B5C-89C65764F35DDB54 [[University of Amsterdam]]: Systems Ecology Department ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603214448/http://www.falw.vu.nl/Onderzoeksinstituten/index.cfm/home_subsection.cfm/subsectionid/55B99586-E22B-4B5C-89C65764F35DDB54 |date=2008-06-03 }}</ref> * [[University of Florida]], Systems Ecology program<ref>[http://www.ees.ufl.edu/homepp/brown/syseco/ [[University of Florida]] Systems Ecology program]</ref> * [[State University of New York College of Environmental Science and Forestry]], Systems Ecology Lab<ref>[http://www.esf.edu/efb/hall/se/ [[State University of New York College of Environmental Science and Forestry]]: Systems ecology Lab]</ref> * [[Stockholm University]], Systems Ecology Department<ref>[http://www.ecology.su.se/ [[Stockholm University]]: Systems Ecology Department]</ref>
=== [[Systems engineering]] === ==== USA ==== * [[GTRI Electronic Systems Laboratory]] (ELSYS) at the Georgia Tech Research Institute, Atlanta, Georgia, USA * [[GTRI Aerospace, Transportation and Advanced Systems Laboratory]] at the Georgia Tech Research Institute, Atlanta, Georgia, USA * [[Western Transportation Institute]] at Montana State University, Montana, USA
==== Europe ==== * [[Hasso Plattner Institute]] related to the University of Potsdam, Germany * [[University of Reading Business School]]: Informatics Research Centre, Reading, Berkshire, England, UK{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * [[École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne]]: I2S – Institut d'ingénierie des systèmes in Lausanne, Switzerland<ref>[http://i2s.epfl.ch/ I2S - Institut d'ingénierie des systèmes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307034229/http://i2s.epfl.ch/ |date=2008-03-07 }}</ref> * [[University of the West of England CEMS]], Systems Engineering Estimation and Decision Support (SEED)<ref>[http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/amrc/seeds/ SEEDS (Systems Engineering Estimation and Decision Support) - Welcome<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120723043105/http://www.cems.uwe.ac.uk/amrc/seeds/ |date=2012-07-23 }}</ref> Bristol, England, UK * University of Bristol, Systems Centre, Bristol, England, UK<ref>[http://www.bris.ac.uk/eng-systems-centre/ Bris.ac.uk]</ref> * [[Technical University of Hamburg]], Hamburg, Germany{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * [[Mullard Space Science Laboratory]]: UCL Centre for Systems Engineering (UCLse), the London, England, UK * Research Centre for Automatic Control (CRAN), joint research unit with [[Nancy-Université]] and [[CNRS]], [[Nancy, France|Nancy]], France<ref>[http://www.cran.uhp-nancy.fr/anglais Cran-uph.nancy.fr]</ref>
== Educational ==
=== Europe === * Bristol Centre for Complexity Sciences, UK<ref>[http://www.bris.ac.uk/bccs/ [[University of Bristol]], United Kingdom. Retrieved {{CURRENTDATE}}]</ref> * Institute for Complex Systems Simulation, University of Southampton, UK<ref name="Southampton ICSS"/>
=== Australia === * The [[University of Sydney]] offers a Master of Complex Systems<ref>http://sydney.edu.au/courses/master-of-complex-systems</ref>
== Societies ==
=== World wide === * [[IEEE Systems, Man & Cybernetics Society]] (IEEE SMCS)<ref>[http://www.ieeesmc.org/ SMC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[International Council on Systems Engineering]] (INCOSE) * [[International Federation for Systems Research]] (IFSR) * [[International Society for the Systems Sciences]] (ISSS) * World Organisation of Systems and Cybernetics (WOSC)<ref>[http://www.cybsoc.org/wosc WOSC index page<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[IEEE Systems Council]] * Complex Systems Society (CSS)<ref>http://cssociety.org/</ref> * [[The International Academy for Systems and Cybernetic Sciences]], an honor society initially created by the IFSR
=== America === * [[American Society for Cybernetics]]<ref>[http://www.asc-cybernetics.org/ American Society for Cybernetics - Index<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Asociacion Mexicana de Systemas y Cibernetica{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * Grupo de Estudio de Sistemas Integrados (GESI) (Study Group of Integrated Systems), Argentina<ref>[http://www.intelligent-systems.com.ar/GESI/gesi.htm Intelligent-systems.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502033141/http://www.intelligent-systems.com.ar/GESI/gesi.htm |date=2007-05-02 }}</ref> * Instituto Andino de Sistemas (IAS), Peru<ref>[http://www.iasvirtual.net/ Instituto Andino de Sistemas - IAS (Lima - Perú): Página Principal (Home Page)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * International Systems Institute (USA), California, San Francisco{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]]<ref>[http://www.lanl.gov/ Los Alamos National Laboratory: National Security Science<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[System Dynamics Society]]: a non-profit organization for further research into system dynamics and systems thinking based in Albany, New York, USA
=== Asia === * International Society of Knowledge and Systems Science (ISKSS), Japan<ref>[http://jasess.u-shizuoka-ken.ac.jp/ 社会・経済システム学会<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706070531/http://jasess.u-shizuoka-ken.ac.jp/ |date=2007-07-06 }}</ref> * Japan Association for Social and Economic Systems Studies (JASESS)<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.ifsr.org/members/ksssr/ IFSR.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070731053614/http://www.ifsr.org/members/ksssr/ |date=2007-07-31 }}</ref> * Korean Society for Systems Science Research, Korea<ref name=autogenerated1 /> * Systems Engineering Society of China<ref>[http://iss02.iss.ac.cn/sesc/ ISS02.iss.ac.cn] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927025946/http://iss02.iss.ac.cn/sesc/ |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref>
=== Australia === * Australia and New Zealand Systems Group (ANZSYS){{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * COSNet: An Australian-based network for Complex Open Systems research<ref>[http://www.complexsystems.net.au/content/about_us COSNet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707162222/http://www.complexsystems.net.au/content/about_us |date=2007-07-07 }}</ref>
=== Europe === * Association Francaise d'Ingénierie Système (French association for Systems Engineering), France<ref>[http://www.afis.fr AFIS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Associazione Italiana per la Ricerca (AIR) (Italian Research Society)<ref>[http://www.associazionericerca.it/ Associazione Italiana per la Ricerca <!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Associazione Italiana per la Ricerca sui Sistemi (AIRS) (Italian Systems Research Society)<ref>[http://www.airs.it/AIRS/indexEN.htm I.S.S. - Italian Systems Society<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Bulgarian Society for Systems Research (BSSR), Bulgaria<ref>[http://www.ifsr.org/members/bssr/ IFSR.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618152355/http://www.ifsr.org/members/bssr/ |date=2007-06-18 }}</ref> * Centre for Hyperincursion and Anticipation in Ordered Systems (CHAOS)<ref>[http://www.ulg.ac.be/mathgen/CHAOS/CHAOS.html Chaos Asbl<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Croatian Interdisciplinary Society]]: a non-governmental organization for interdisciplinary education and research in complex systems in Croatia * [[Cybernetics Society]], London, UK<ref>[http://www.cybsoc.org/ The Cybernetics Society<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Dutch Systems Group]] of ''Systemsgroep Nederland'', The Netherlands<ref>[http://www.cict.demon.co.uk/systeemgroep.html Systeemgroep<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Evolution, Complexity and Cognition group, University of Brussels, Belgium<ref>[http://pcp.vub.ac.be/ECCO/ PCP.vub.ac.be]</ref> * [[Hellenic Society for Systemic Studies]] (HSSS) Ελληνική Εταρεία Συστημικών Μελετών<ref>[http://www.hsss.gr/eng/index.html HSSS.gr]</ref> * Gesellschaft für Wirtschaft und Sozial-Kybernetik e. (GWS), Germany<ref>[http://www.gws-kybernetik.org/ Gesellschaft für Wirtschafts- und Sozialkybernetik e.V<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Learned Society of Praxiology, Poland{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} * MSSI - Management Science Society of Ireland<ref>[http://mis.ucd.ie/cmss Welcome to CMSS — mis.ucd.ie<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Österreichische Studiengesellschaft für Kybernetik (OSGK)(Austrian Society for Cybernetic Studies), Austria<ref>[http://www.osgk.ac.at/ Oesterreichische Studiengesellschaft fuer Kybernetik (OESGK) (21-Feb-1996)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Polish Systems Society, Poland<ref>[http://www.pwr.wroc.pl/ Politechnika Wrocławska - Strona główna<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Slovenian Society for Systems Research (SDSR)<ref>[http://epfip.uni-mb.si/ Institute for Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * Sociedad Española de Systemas Generales, Spain<ref>[http://www.uv.es/~pla/SESGE/ Sociedad Española de Sistemas Generales<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * United Kingdom Systems Society, UK<ref>[http://www.ukss.org.uk/ UK Systems Society<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

{{Infobox Laboratory |name = Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom |image = |established = 1884 |budget = |research_field = [[Marine science]] |head = Professor Colin Brownlee (Director) |affiliations = |staff = |students = |city = [[Plymouth]] |address = The Laboratory, Citadel Hill, PL1 2PB |website = {{URL|http://www.mba.ac.uk }} |logo = }}
The '''Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom''' (MBA) is a [[learned society]] with a scientific laboratory that undertakes research in [[marine biology]].<ref name="Southward">{{cite journal |author=A. J. Southward & E. K. Roberts |year=1987 |title=One hundred years of marine research at Plymouth |journal=[[Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom]] |volume=67 |issue=3 |pages=465–506 |doi=10.1017/S0025315400027259 |url=http://plymsea.ac.uk/286/}}</ref> The organisation was founded in 1884 and has been based in [[Plymouth]] since the Citadel Hill Laboratory was opened on 30 June 1888. It has a world-leading reputation for marine biological research, with some twelve Nobel laureates having been or being associated with it over the course of their career. Among them, [[A. V. Hill]] received the [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] in 1922 "for his discovery relating to the production of heat in the muscle".<ref>{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1922|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1922/|accessdate=16 May 2012}}</ref> The discovery of the mechanism of [[nerve impulses]] ([[action potentials]]) in animals was made at the Laboratory in Plymouth by Sir [[Alan Lloyd Hodgkin]] and Sir [[Andrew Huxley]], work for which they were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1963. The MBA publishes the ''[[Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mba.ac.uk/about.php |title=About the MBA |publisher=Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom |accessdate=February 25, 2009}}</ref> The MBA is also home to the National Marine Biological Library, whose collections cover the marine biological sciences, and curates the Historical Collections.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Marine Biological Library|url=http://www.mba.ac.uk/NMBL/}}</ref><ref>MBA Historical Collections (http://www.mba.ac.uk/nmbl/projects)</ref> Throughout its history, the MBA has had a Royal Patron. The current patron of the MBA is [http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/TheDukeofEdinburgh.aspx H.R.H. The Prince Philip], Duke of Edinburgh. In 2013, the MBA was granted a [[Royal Charter]] in recognition of the MBA's scientific preeminence in its field.<ref>"A Royal Charter for the MBA" http://www.mba.ac.uk/membership/a-royal-charter-for-the-marine-biological-association/</ref>
==Origins and foundation== In 1866 the [[Royal Commission]] on the Sea Fisheries, which included among its officers Professor [[Thomas Henry Huxley]], had reported that fears of over-exploitation of the sea fisheries were unfounded.<ref>J. Caird, T. H. Huxley & G. S. Lefevre (1866) Report of the Commissioners Appointed to Enquire into the Sea Fisheries of the United Kingdom. London HMSO, Vol. I, 108 pp.</ref> They recommended removing existing laws regulating fishing grounds and closed seasons. However, the increase in the size and number of fishing vessels was causing widespread concern, and there were reports from all around the UK coasts about the scarcity of particular fish. This concern was expressed at the [[International Fisheries Exhibition]] in London in 1883, a conference called to discuss the commercial and scientific aspects of the fishing industry, and which was attended by many leading scientists of the day. Nevertheless, in his opening address,<ref>T. H. Huxley (1884) Inaugural address. International Fisheries Exhibition, 1883, Literature, 4, 1-19.</ref> Huxley discounted reports of fish scarcities and repeated the views of the Royal Commission of 1866. He stated that with existing methods of fishing, it was inconceivable that the great sea fisheries, such as those for cod (''[[Gadus morhua]]''), herring (''[[Clupea harengus]]'') and mackerel (''[[Scomber scombrus]]''), could ever be exhausted.
Many of the representatives of science and commerce present had different views to Huxley. Their views were put forward by [[E. Ray Lankester]], who summed up the scientific contributions in an essay on what we would now call ecology. He pointed out that "it is a mistake to suppose that the place of fish removed from a particular fishing ground is immediately taken by some of the grand total of fish, which are so numerous in comparison with man's depredations as to make his operations in this respect insignificant...there is on the contrary evidence that shoal fish, like herrings, mackerel and pilchard (''[[Sardina pilchardus]]''), and ground-fish, such as soles and other flat-fishes, are really localised. If man removes a large proportion of these fish from the areas which they inhabit, the natural balance is upset and chiefly in so far as the production of young fish is concerned."<ref>E. R. Lankester (1884) The scientific results of the exhibition. International Fisheries Exhibition, 1883, Literature, 4, 443-446.</ref> During this masterly address he went on to develop this theme and concluded with an appeal for the formation of a society to foster the study of marine life, both for its scientific interest and because of the need to know more about the life histories and habitats of food fishes. Professor Lankester envisaged that such a society would construct a laboratory close to the coast, with the building containing aquaria and apparatus for the circulation of seawater and, most importantly, laboratory accommodation for scientists. The appeal was answered by a group of eminent scientists, who resolved to form a society and build a laboratory on the British coast.
===Founders=== The Committee formed at the International Fisheries Exhibition 1883 resolved to take action to establish a British Marine Laboratory, an initiative that ultimately led to the formation of the Marine Biological Association and building of the Laboratory in Plymouth. They were: * [[John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury|Sir John Lubbock]], MP (later Lord Avebury) * [[Philip Sclater|P. L. Sclater]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Secretary of the [[Zoological Society of London|Zoological Society]] * [[F. Jeffrey Bell]], Professor of Zoology at [[King's College London]] * [[Michael Foster (physiologist)|Michael Foster]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Professor of Physiology at [[University of Cambridge]] * [[John Scott Burdon-Sanderson|J. Burdon-Sanderson]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Professor of Physiology at [[University of Oxford]] * [[William Henry Flower|W. H. Flower]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Hunterian Professor, [[Royal College of Surgeons of England|Royal College of Surgeons]] * [[George Romanes|G. J. Romanes]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Secretary of the [[Linnean Society]] * [[Adam Sedgwick|A. Sedgwick]], [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] * [[Henry Nottidge Moseley|H. N. Moseley]], Linacre Professor of Anatomy at University of Oxford * [[A. Milnes Marshall]], Professor of Zoology at [[University of Manchester]] * [[William Turner Thiselton-Dyer|W. T. Thiselton-Dyer]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Assistant Director, [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]] * [[William Benjamin Carpenter|W. B. Carpenter]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * [[George James Allman|G. J. Allman]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], Emeritus Professor of Natural History at [[University of Edinburgh]] * [[John Murray (oceanographer)|John Murray]], Director of the [[Challenger Expedition]] Reports
The Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom was formed at a meeting held in the rooms of the [[Royal Society]] in London on 31 March 1884. All but two of the signatories of the resolution of 1883 were present, together with some other scientists. By this time Professor Huxley had been persuaded to give his support and was elected as the first President of the Association, with Ray Lankester as Honorary Secretary.
==Presidents and Directors== The MBA is governed by a [http://www.mba.ac.uk/governance/ Council] which is headed by a President. The MBA's Director is responsible for the day-to-day running of the Association.
===Presidents=== Since 1884, the MBA has had fifteen Presidents.:<ref name="Southward"/><ref>http://www.mba.ac.uk/nmbl/projects/people/presidents</ref> * T. H. Huxley [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1884 to 1890) * Sir E. Ray Lankester [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1890 to 1929) * [[Walter Guinness, 1st Baron Moyne|Lord Moyne]] (1930 to 1939) * [[George Parker Bidder III|George Parker Bidder]] (1939 to 1945) * Sir [[James Gray (zoologist)|James Gray]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1945 to 1955) * A. V. Hill [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1955 to 1960) * [[Carl Pantin|C. F. A. Pantin]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1960 to 1966) * Sir [[Alan Lloyd Hodgkin|Alan L. Hodgkin]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1966 to 1976) * [[J. Z. Young]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1976 to 1986) * [[James Lovelock]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (1986 to 1990) * Sir [[Crispin Tickell]] (1990 to 2001) * Sir [[Neil Chalmers]] (2002 to 2007) * Sir [[Howard Dalton]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (2007 to 2008) * Sir [[Geoffrey Holland]] (2008 to 2014) * Sir [[John Beddington]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (2014 to present)
===Directors=== There have been fourteen directors of the Marine Biological Association since its foundation: * 1884–1888: Walter Heape [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1888–1890: Gilbert C. Bourne [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1890–1892: [[William L. Calderwood]] * 1892–1894: [[Edward J. Bles]] [[FRSE]] * 1894–1936: [[Edgar Johnson Allen]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1936–1945: [[Stanley Wells Kemp|Stanley W. Kemp]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1945–1965: Sir [[Frederick Stratten Russell|Frederick S. Russell]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1965–1974: Sir [[James Eric Smith|J. Eric Smith]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1974–1987: Sir [[Eric James Denton|Eric J. Denton]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] * 1987–1999: [[Michael Whitfield]] * 1999–2007: [[Stephen J. Hawkins]] * 2007–2017: [http://www.mba.ac.uk/fellows/professor-colin-brownlee/ Colin Brownlee] * 2017-2018: Matthew T Frost * 2018 -- : William H. Wilson
==Current Research Programme== The MBA research programme reflects a long-standing commitment to the development of marine biology. It addresses both fundamental and strategic issues in marine science and is structured around two principal themes: [http://www.mba.ac.uk/ecology/ Ecosystems and Environmental Change], and the [http://www.mba.ac.uk/molecular/ Mechanisms Underlying Biogeochemical and Ecological Processes].
The research programme covers a range of disciplines including [[cell biology]], [[physiology]] and functional biology, [[phytoplankton]] dynamics, [[ecology]] and [[animal behaviour]] and [[ecosystem]] change. An overarching rationale for the MBA research programme is to understand mechanisms that underlie key marine life processes. This includes research on model marine organisms that informs a broader knowledge of fundamental mechanisms as well as research that is specifically targeted at understanding biogeochemical and ecological processes and their complex interactions with environmental factors, including long-term and rapid [[environmental change]]. [http://www.mba.ac.uk/long-term-change/ Long-term science] observations of physical and biological parameters in the ocean have been collected by the MBA for over 100 years providing a foundation of data supporting studies aimed at understanding biological responses to marine environmental changes including effects of [[climate change]].
The research programme is managed by the MBA Council through its Director and Deputy Director (Research) with the prime aim being to promote individually motivated research into problems of fundamental importance in marine biology. This is achieved by interweaving the work of resident [http://www.mba.ac.uk/research-staff/ Research Fellows] with that of visiting workers. The groundbreaking work of MBA research scientists has been recognised by many national and international awards over the years, including the Royal Society's [[Royal Medal]], [[Darwin Medal]] and [[Croonian Lecture]], the Zoological Society of London's [[Frink Medal]], and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science's [[International Prize for Biology]].
==National Marine Biological Library== The National Marine Biological Library (NMBL) began in 1887 as the research support library for the MBA.<ref name="Southward"/> Today, it provides research support for the MBA, the [[Continuous Plankton Recorder|Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science]] and [[Plymouth Marine Laboratory]]. The NMBL's holdings include periodicals, serials, journals, reports and grey literature, a large collection of historical and modern books, an extensive reprint collection, and expedition reports. These cover the vast majority of the world. The NMBL’s Special Collections include the research libraries of several eminent MBA scientists; these are [[George Parker Bidder (marine biologist)|George Parker Bidder]], [[Edward Thomas Browne]], [[Sidney Frederic Harmer]], [[E. Ray Lankester]], [[Marie Victoire Lebour]] and [[John Zachary Young]]. Additionally, the NMBL curates the MBA Archive Collection which details the MBA's institutional history as well the history of marine biology in Britain since the late-nineteenth century, especially through the collection’s personal papers. These include scientific papers and material from [[Walter Garstang]], [[Sidney Frederic Harmer|Sidney Harmer]], [[H. W. Harvey|Hildebrand Wolfe Harvey]], [[Thomas Hincks]], [[Thomas Vere Hodgson|Thomas V. Hodgson]], [[Stanley W. Kemp]], [[Charles Atwood Kofoid|Charles A. Kofoid]], [[Mary Parke]], [[John Richardson (naturalist)|John Richardson]], [[Frederick Stratten Russell|Frederick S. Russell]], [[Thomas Alan Stephenson|Thomas A. Stephenson]], [[Walter Frank Raphael Weldon]], [[Edward A. Wilson]] and [[William Yarrell]].
==''Journal of the Marine Biological Association''== {{Main|Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom}} Since 1887, the MBA has published the ''Journal of the Marine Biological Association'' (JMBA), a scientific journal "publishing original research on all aspects of marine biology".<ref>{{cite web|title=JMBA: The Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom|url=http://www.mba.ac.uk/jmba|accessdate=4 July 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox religious building | name = Nanzo-in
南蔵院 | native_name = | image = Reclining Buddha statues of Nanzoin.jpg | image_size = 300 | alt = | caption = | map_type = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = 1035, [[Sasaguri]], Sasaguri-machi, Kasuya-gun, [[Fukuoka]] | coordinates = | religious_affiliation = Shingon | deity = | country = Japan | functional_status = | website = http://www.nanzoin.com/ (Japanese only) | founded_by = Hayashi Satoshiun | year_completed = 1899 }} '''Nanzo-in''' ({{Nihongo2|南蔵院|help=yes}}) is a Shingon sect Buddhist temple in Sasaguri, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan. It is notable for its bronze statue of a reclining Buddha, said to be the largest bronze statue in the world. ==History== [[File:Gate of Nanzoin Temple in Sasaguri, Kasuya, Fukuoka.JPG|thumb|Gate to Nanzoin Temple in Sasaguri, Fukuoka, Japan.]] Nanzo-in temple was originally located on [[Mountain Kōya|Mt. Koyasan]], but local anti-Buddhist authorities threatened to destroy the temple in 1886{{Cite web|url=https://www.japan.travel/in/spot/2167/|title=Nanzo-in Temple|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. Public outcry lead to a decade-long effort to have the temple transferred to [[Sasaguri, Fukuoka|Sasaguri]].{{cite book|last1=ACROS|first1=Fukuoka|title=Fukuoka Guide Spring 2011|date=2011|publisher=ACROS Fukuoka}} It was moved in 1899, under the leadership of Sasaguri priest, Hayashi Satoshiun.{{cite web|last1=Kanko|first1=Sasaguri|title=Sasaguri Tourism: Nanzoin Temple (Japanese)|url=http://www.sasagurikanko.com/temple/nanzoin/|website=Sasagurikanko.com|accessdate=9 December 2015}} Nanzo-in temple is the main location among the 88 temples that make up the Sasaguri pilgrimage route, one of the three famous walking [[pilgrimage]]s in Japan. Today, the temple and its surrounding grounds receive more than 1 million visitors annually.{{cite web|last1=Fukuoka|first1=Crossroads|title=Nanzoin Temple|url=http://www.crossroadfukuoka.jp/en/event/?mode=detail&id=4000000000402&isSpot=1|publisher=Crossroads}} ===Lottery=== A chief priest of Nanzo-in temple once won the lottery after laying his ticket next to a statue of [[Daikokuten|Daikoku]]{{Cite web|url=https://taiken.co/single/nanzo-in-temple-the-reclining-buddha-temple/|title=Nanzo-in Temple: The Reclining Buddha Temple|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. The temple claims that others who have made a similar effort have also won the lottery, bringing the temple associations with luck and lottery tickets.{{Cite web|url=https://bemarietravels.com/nanzoin-temple-fukuoka/|title=The Beautiful Nanzoin Temple Fukuoka|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Reclining Buddha== [[File:Reclining Buddha in Nanzoin Temple 20150429.JPG|thumb|The reclining Buddha statue at Nanzoin Temple in Sasaguri, Fukuoka, Japan.]] The reclining [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] statue, known as either ''Nehanzo'' or ''Shaka Nehan'' ("Nirvana"){{cite web|title=Karmic Cleansing|url=http://www.macleans.ca/society/life/karmic-cleansing/|website=Macleans.ca|accessdate=9 December 2015}} is 41 meters long, 11 meters high, and weighs nearly 300 tons.{{cite book|last1=Sasaguri-shi|title=Sasaguri Sight-Seeing Spots|publisher=Sasaguri Town|url=http://www.town.sasaguri.fukuoka.jp/userfiles/files/data/create/lecture/sightseeing_spots.pdf}} The statue depicts Buddha at the moment of death, or entrance into [[nirvana]]. The interior holds ashes of Buddha and two Buddhist adherents, [[Ananda]] and [[Maudgalyayana]]. Those relics were a gift from Myanmar as thanks for the sect's donations of medical supplies to children in both [[Nepal]] and [[Myanmar]]. In 1995, 1,300 monks from Myanmar and Nepal attended the unveiling of the reclining Buddha statue. Inside the sculpture, sand from each of the 88 shrines that make up the [[Shikoku Pilgrimage|Shikoku pilgrimage]] are stored below bricks within a narrow hallway.{{cite web|last1=Nakamura|first1=Connie|title=Sasaguri Town - Mini Pilgrimage And More!|url=http://taiken.co/single/sasaguri-town-mini-pilgrimage-and-more|website=Taiken.co|publisher=Taiken|accessdate=9 December 2015}} Every year, hundreds of Buddhists come together to clean the statue using bamboo leaves tied to five-meter poles. ==Funerals== Nanzo-in Temple has 4,315 ''nokotsudo,'' places where bones of the deceased are stored. The temple has a non-traditional fee structure for housing remains. First, it is open to all sects of Buddhism, and is even open to [[Shinto]] remains. Secondly, many Buddhist temples rely on a monthly fee for housing the bones of the deceased, which are then disposed of after a set period of time. Nanzo-in Temple has one fee, which covers 200 years.{{cite book|last1=Bryant|first1=Clifton|title=Handbook of Death and Dying|date=2003|publisher=SAGE|page=668}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord|33.619839|N|130.572935|E|region:JP_type:city|display=title}} [[Category:Buddhist temples in Fukuoka Prefecture]] [[Category:Buddha statues]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fukuoka Prefecture]] [[Category:Shingon Buddhism]] [[Category:Buddhist art]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} [[File:National Humanities Medal cropped.jpg|thumb|right|The obverse of the National Humanities Medal]]
The '''National Humanities Medal''' is an American award that annually recognizes several individuals, groups, or institutions for work that has "deepened the nation's understanding of the humanities, broadened our citizens' engagement with the humanities, or helped preserve and expand Americans' access to important resources in the humanities."<ref name=awards>{{cite web |url=http://www.neh.gov/whoweare/awards.html |title=Awards and Honors |publisher=[[National Endowment for the Humanities]] |accessdate=January 23, 2009}}</ref> <!-- is it always, or always nowadays, or not always conferred ceremonially by the US President? -->
The annual '''[[Charles Frankel]] Prize in the Humanities''' was established in 1988 and succeeded by the National Humanities Medal in 1997. The initial design for the National Humanities Medal was created by a 1995 Frankel Prize winner, [[David Macaulay]], and was used for all recipients through 2012.<ref name=awards /> During 2013, The National Endowment for the Humanities ran a public competition for a new medal design, judged by metalsmith [[Chunghi Choo]], coin engraver [[Don Everhart]] of the [[United States Mint|U.S. Mint]] and sculptor [[George Anthonisen]]. In June 2013, the agency announced that a design by Paul C. Balan of Illinois had been selected as the winner. The final medal will be unveiled in Washington D.C. in November 2013. The new design was used for the first time for the 2013 National Humanities Medals, which were presented in mid-2014.<ref name=NewNHM2013>{{cite web |title=Paul C. Balan National Humanities Medal design |publisher=National Endowment for the Humanities |url=http://humanitiesmedaldesign.challengepost.com/submissions/14016-paul-c-balan-national-humanities-medal-design |website=Challenge.gov |accessdate=July 6, 2005}}</ref>
{{external media | width = 210px | float = right | video1 = [https://www.whitehouse.gov/photos-and-video/video/2016/09/22/president-obama-awards-arts-humanities-medal President Obama Awards the Arts & Humanities Medal], September 22, 2016, 30:51, [[The White House]]<ref name="potus">{{cite web | title =President Obama Awards the Arts & Humanities Medal | work = | publisher =[[The White House]] | date =September 22, 2016 | url =https://www.whitehouse.gov/photos-and-video/video/2016/09/22/president-obama-awards-arts-humanities-medal | accessdate =September 22, 2016 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160923090135/https://www.whitehouse.gov/photos-and-video/video/2016/09/22/president-obama-awards-arts-humanities-medal | archivedate =September 23, 2016 | df =mdy-all }}</ref> }} Medals are conferred once annually, usually by the U.S. President, to as many as twelve living candidates and existing organizations nominated early in the calendar year. The President selects the winners in consultation with the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]].<ref name=nominations>{{cite web |url=http://www.neh.gov/whoweare/medalsnominate.html |title=National Humanities Medals Nominations |publisher=National Endowment for the Humanities |accessdate=March 18, 2012}}</ref>
NEH asks that nominators consult the list of previous winners and consider the [[National Medal of Arts]] to recognize contributions in "the creative or performing arts".<ref name=nominations />
